talk.start.para: âI present the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the Commonwealth privacy legislation, together with submissions and the Hansard record of the proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish to express my joy at being able to present this report to the chamber today. It has been a long time in gestation, the reference being given to the committee in May 1998 and public hearings being held in July and August last year, with an anticipated reporting date in August. However, Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that the sitting pattern was somewhat changed last year with the calling of an early election and that the parliament did not meet again until November last year, when new committees and committee chairs were put in place.

The chairman's draft report was given to the committee on 7 December last year, shortly before the Senate adjourned for the Christmas break. There has been what could be seen as a response to the report, even before the report was brought down. The Attorney-General, in a major statement in January this year, brought down a revised version of the National Principles for the Fair Handling of Personal Information. I am very pleased that the Attorney did so but, had he done so earlier, perhaps in July last year, it would have saved the committee quite a deal of work. But at least it does prove that the Attorney and the Attorney-General's Department are listening to what the community is saying. We do await the hard copy of what the Attorney said the government is going to do in that statement delivered in January this year.

Before I speak briefly on the body of the report, I also pay tribute to the secretariat that assisted the committee in the development of the report. Dr Pauline Moore, as the secretary of the committee, was ably assisted by Mr Jonathan Curtis, Mr Gavin Denton and Ms Alison Carson. I thank them for their assistance and advice in the development of the report. I also have to thank my colleagues, in particular the former deputy chair of the committee who ably assisted me during the inquiry, Senator Abetz, and, of course, a previous member of the committee, Senator George Campbell. I must also thank my friend and colleague the learned Senator Cooney from Victoria, who was a constant source of advice and counsel during the inquiry. He also assisted immeasurably during the construction of the report which is now presented to the Senate.

The terms of reference of the inquiry asked the committee to consider measures contained in the Privacy Amendment Bill 1998, which proposed to extend the operation of the Privacy Act 1998 to business performing work outsourced by the Commonwealth, together with existing privacy protection in Australia's private sector, taking into account Australia's international obligations and the need for legislative backing for privacy protection. The report addresses those needs in the private sector, the extent to which the current protection is offered and the effectiveness of a self-regulatory system. Although the 1998 bill is not yet back on the Notice Paper, the inquiry is broader than what was proposed within that legislation.

Since the inquiry commenced, the Stockdale bill has been introduced in Victoria, prompting the federal government to change its policy and accept the need for at least some legislative protection of privacy in the private sector. The committee has not considered the developments since December last year. To do so would have meant that we would have restarted the inquiry, and of course we have not yet seen the colour of the content of what the Attorney-General is proposing. He has stated what they are going to do, but what is going to be proposed is not yet public. We await that with bated breath.

The international and national debates over privacy protection have resulted in an emergence of an expanding body of law and standards. A privacy protection scheme covering the private sector must include core information protection principles and an enforcement system. These must create enforceable rights and obligations that provide minimum standards of an individual's privacy right. The privacy protection principles should reflect international best practice, such as the European Union Directive on Data Protection. A failure to ensure high standards could damage Australia's trade interests in two ways: by inhibiting the ability of trade partners to exchange information and by limiting the confidence of the Australian public in emerging technologies.

The committee concludes that existing protection is inadequate. Australia's existing legal frameworks are partial in their coverage and vary across jurisdictions. Access to remedies and enforcement is uncertain. Inadequacy of federal law is prompting legislative responses at a state and territory level, making a fragmented national approach increasingly likely. Self-regulation by itself does not provide an adequate system for privacy protection. Without an adequate enforcement mechanism, the national principles for the fair handling of privacy information lack force and cannot provide the basis for an effective national privacy scheme.

The national principles do not meet the requirements of the European Union Directive on Data Protection. In comparison, they provide a weak and piecemeal approach to the collection and protection of data. The Privacy Amendment Bill 1998 is an inadequate response to the need for privacy legislation. The desire to minimise the application of the bill would have had the effect of increasing the complexity of Australia's privacy laws. This is ironic, considering industry's pleas for simplified, uniform and consistent privacy laws.

The committee recommends the creation of uniform national legislation covering both the public and the private sectors. The preferred solution is a coregulatory system based on a model developed by the Attorney-General's Department. This comprises flexible industry codes developed in cooperation with the Privacy Commissioner and backed by a legislative scheme. Responses received to the 1996 discussion paper Privacy Protection in the Private Sector reveal an overwhelming support within industry for the proposed coregulatory model. Minimising the regulatory burden and compliance costs to industry is important. However, costs depend upon the exact nature of the scheme in question. It cannot be assumed that a legislative system will necessarily entail high compliance costs. The coregulatory model adopted in New Zealand has cost very little.

There is a wide constitutional basis for the Commonwealth parliament to enact comprehensive privacy legislation, although there may be some doubt as to the complete coverage of such legislation across all areas. However, this problem could be solved by the enactment of uniform model legislation in all jurisdictions by Commonwealth, state and territory governments. I commend the report to the chamber.

talk.start.para: âThis is a vital report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee in the discussion about what privacy laws we ought to have in this country and, indeed, what we ought to have around the world. I say `around the world' because a lot of the impetus for this report came from the European directive of which Senator McKiernan has spoken. Senator McKiernan chaired this committee and, in his usual able way, has led the committee to make a very significant contribution to the area that we are discussing.

speech.para: The whole issue of privacy is one that is going to trouble us for some time because it goes to the issue of what information should be made available to the public generally and what should not. Of course, in this era of technology it is very hard for people to keep secure to themselves what they might wish to. The answer to this problem of how information is to be controlled might end up being resolved by making information more available. That is a very interesting concept. Instead of trying to shut off the access that other people have to information about ourselves, if we made that information available to everybody on the basis that everybody made information about themselves available to the world, then an interesting situation would arise. That would mean that we would no longer have problems with the concept of commercial-in-confidence, for example. If a company did not want compulsory regulation of privacy matters but left it up to the goodwill of others and information that would tell us how that company was acting became available, then so be it.

That sort of approach might indicate that if you have nothing to hide you have nothing to fear. What I have been talking about might indicate that that phrase is not as easily applied as it might first appear because if that were the case it would mean that these commercial-in-confidence issues and other similar issues would become available to the public. We have instances in this chamber which ariseâone arose yesterdayâas to what documents should be made available in the Senate. What proper role does the executive have and what proper role does the parliament have in this question of what information should be made available?

In the area of policing, what documents should be kept away from the police and what documents should the police be able to preserve when they have them? In matters of national security there are great issues. What information should be made available about Pine Gap and what should not be made available? There is a whole area in which privacy has yet to be discussed, but the fundamental issue is the same: what should we, as a matter of right, be able to keep to ourselves, whether we are a government, a party, a military organisation, a police force or whether we are a company trading in commodities or anything else? That is what this issue goes to. Therefore, it is a very important issue.

As we see things, if people find out supposed information about us then the issue arises as to what sort of interpretation they are going to put upon that information. Let me explain further. People say that if you have nothing to fear you have nothing to hide. But that presumes that what is revealed about us or about our company, our country or our party will be interpreted by others in a fair way. One of the great problems in this area is the interpretation that is given to information that becomes available about anything or anybody. That information is often very badly interpreted. So you get information put out to the public which is incorrect, which is given a twist or a spin, as they say, and then comes back in a very unfair way on the person about whom the information has been made available.

I would like to have heard many people in this chamber discuss this document because it is, as I say, a very central issue in our society. It is a matter that affects all of us because there are all sorts of things which we do not want people to know about our own livesâour medical records, for instance. Even in dealings within one political party some people might say, `We will keep those sorts of deals secret.' That does not happen on our side of politics because whatever we do we reveal and it is plain for all to see. But in other places, people do deals which they want to keep secret. It would be a terrible shock to our side to think that that sort of thing happened.

The issue of privacy comes in at every level and in all areas. I am glad that Senator McKiernan had the perspicacity to see that it ought to be developed. I should mention the rest of the committeeâSenator Payne, who has recently come to this committee and is quite outstanding, Senator Coonan, Senator Hutchins and Senator Stott-Despoja. In closing, I thank the staff in the secretariat who did the work. Senator McKiernan has already thanked them, but I would also like to mention Dr Pauline Moore, Mr Jonathan Curtis, Mr Gavin Denton and Ms Alison Carson.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell)âas amended, by leaveâproposed:
(1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Information Technologies, be appointed to inquire into and report on such matters as may be referred to it by the Senate.

(2) That the committee consist of 8 senators, 4 to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, 1 to be nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, and 1 to be nominated by an independent senator or a Green senator.
(3) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the chair be elected from the government members of the committee.
(5) That the deputy chair be elected from the non-government members immediately after the election of the chair.
(6) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(7) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

(8) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such recommendations as it may deem fit.

(9) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider.

(10) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(11) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.
(12) The committee have power to consider and use for its purposes the minutes of evidence and records of the select committees on:
Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies;
Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies; and
Information Technologies.
(13) That the committee shall present its final report on any matters referred to it on or before, and cease to exist on, the last day of sitting in the year 2000.

talk.start.para: âI would like to make a brief statement. The central problem with this motion is that the proposed committee has no terms of reference. The matter of information technology is a critical one to everybody in our community. The Greens in particular, representing very strongly the interests of young Australians, are concerned to see that information technology is facilitated, not restricted. We are particularly concerned that, if a committee like this is established, it look at such matters as foreign ownership and cross- media ownership, noting the comments by Messrs Packer in the last 24 hours about the convergence of computer and communications technology which, in their viewâand this is a revised viewâmakes the attempt to limit foreign ownership of the media, in the widest sense of that word, obsolete.

speech.para: We are also concerned about equity of access to information technology so that there is equal opportunity for students in Australia's schools, for people in the bush vis-a-vis those in the city and for community groups. Add to that those people who find information technology difficultâolder people, people with physical handicaps or impediments and people who are not literate or who do not have English as their first language. I would like to see a committee like this look at positive action to ensure that those Australians who find information technology is outside their reach have it brought within their reach. We see continuing analysis of the penetration of computers into, for example, households in Australia, noting it is probably higher than in almost any other country, and yet 10, 20 or 30 per cent of households in Australia have never seen a computer cross the threshold. So we see there a difficulty for many Australians. I would also like to see an analysis of the impact of information technology on the regulation of commerce, on taxation and on the way in which Australians go about their everyday lives.

I note that there is already an Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee. We already have a committee which could handle the work that we presume the government intends for the committee now before the Senate. Why have two committees dealing with information technology? Why not expand the terms of reference of an established committee dealing with information technology? This is confusing, it is unusual. It will, I presume, if we are to be expeditious, require demarcation as to what matters those two committeesâthe established committee and the one to be establishedâare going to look at with regard to information technology.

Above all, we have to allay the concern there is in the community that this is going to be the anti-porn crusade committee; that at times unspecified in the future we are going to see the issue of censorship at the top of the agenda of this committee looking into information technology. I do not want to see that happen. I do not believe that the most important thing regarding information technology in this country and the problems it presents for the average citizen is the truncation of the liberties of Australians to see, read or hear what they wish to.

Obviously, all of us have concerns about the excesses which can be engaged in here; concerns which are going to be a huge problem not just for people in this country but for people right around the world because, as we all know, the control of information technology does not start or finish at the borders of this or any other country. The regulation of what can be seen or heard by Australians needs to be constantly looked at. But if this committee is being designedâand there is every appearance that it is being designedâto further the interests of Senator Harradine and members of the government in cracking down on what Australians can see or read about, then that is a matter of great concern. If that is the case, let it be said. Let us be open and straight about it now. I reiterate: there are hugely important matters to do with information technology which the Senate should be looking at. They can be looked at by an established committee. Why create another one and, in particular, why bring another one with no terms of reference before the Senate for consideration?

What is going on here? Why has the government suddenly, at this time, brought this committee up for consideration by the Senate with no terms of reference? I suggest it is to foster the interests of Senator Harradine. I suggest it is to have available a means of looking at material on the Internet which Senator Harradine is concerned about. I note that this matter is up for consideration, whereas other matters that Senator Harradine has not had time to deal with are put off until next week. I might be wrong about this, but let us have a debate about it. There is, I can tell you, a very wide concern out in the community that we are entering a new age of censorship, that we are entering a new age of government interference in the liberties of Australiansâtime-honoured and time-held liberties. If that is the case, let us call a spade a spade. Let the government tell this Senate what it is up to.

In the absence of proper terms of reference, the government is simply fostering the concern there is in the community that agenda number one here is to facilitate Senator Harradine's concern for censorship, while at the same time the government facilitates its concern to get through the sale of more of Telstra, to get through its GST legislation, to get through its anti-environmental laws, to get through its anti-forest protection laws and so on. I am not going to support the appointment of a committee that has no terms of reference. The two things should be here together. We should have the agenda on the table. It is not on the table and, until it is on the table, I will be opposing it.

talk.start.para: âWill you run for membership if it gets set up without the terms of reference?
âI am coming right to that, Senator Campbell. Yes, I will be standing for this committee if it is set up with or without terms of reference, for the very reasons I have just expounded.
âI helped write the terms of reference, Bob. This is the old committee. It is the old terms of references. That is my understanding, but you could seek clarification.

âSenator Stott Despoja says it is the old terms of reference which she helped write. The question goes back, `Well, is it?' And the question is, Senator Stott Despoja: why has this matter come before the Senate right now? And you will be able to answer that.
âWhy did the Dee Margetts one come before the Senate last week? Is there some magic about it? Is there a conspiracy?

âYou can speak for yourself. I will answer your question, Senator Campbell. Senator Campbell has asked whether I will stand for this committee whether or not it has terms of reference. He is not sure then what the terms of reference are, Senator Stott Despoja. He does not know that these are the terms of reference we are going to end up with here. I would like to hear that confirmed. If it is confirmed, then I will rest easier with it. The Greens do have an enormous interest in information technology and its ramifications for the Australian community. So of course I would be interested in seeing whatever evidence comes before a committee like this and in helping to evaluate that evidence in the interests of the Australian community.

âUnlike Senator Brown's, my contribution will not go to the issue of the motivations of the government for establishing the committee. But I want to refer to some issues which I believe are issues of substance and ought to be taken seriously by the Senate. We have heard Senator Brown's contribution in relation to the committee not having terms of reference. This refers to paragraph (1) of the motion before us, which states:

speech.para: That a Select Committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Information Technologies, be appointed to inquire into and report on such matters as may be referred to it by the Senate.

We do not really know at this stage what reference this committee may receive from the Senate. In the absence of, if you like to use the terminology, formal terms of reference, I think there are some issues of concern that we need to give consideration to. I am concerned that in this situation of establishing a committee without a specific job to doâin other words, establishing a committee with nothing to inquire into formallyâ
Senator Harradine interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI hear from you, Senator Harradine. If you just listen to what I am saying, I am just putting what I think is the technical issue. I am not going to motivations here, as I have indicated.
âNeither am I.

âSo let me just tell you what I think the problem is. We are establishing a committee that does not have at this stageâof course it might have soonâmatters to report into. I am concerned that in this circumstance we might determine the membership and even establish the chair of the committeeâthe chair may even be being paid a salary of officeâbut we might not actually have any formal work for the committee to undertake. I think that is a significant issue for the Senate and we need to be careful about it. Paragraph (1) of this motion refers to appointing a committee `to inquire into and report on such matters as may be referred to it by the Senate'. And the technical issue is: no matters at this stage have been referred to it by the Senate. I do not know whether they will be or not.
âThey have been, and this is the report.

âWhere is that in the motion, Brian? I am listening to the interjection from Senator Harradine, because I am interested in what he says on this. I have carefully read the motion, all 12 paragraphs of the motion before us, and the 13th, which the Manager of Government Business has by leave incorporated in the motion. That is something that is supported by the opposition, because in fact it was the opposition's idea. It was the opposition that went to the government and said, `Well, you now have a proposition before the Senate involving the establishment of a select committee, but there is no report back date.' So that was a matter of concern, as I am sure all senators would appreciate. At the initiative of the opposition we now have incorporated in the motionâin my view, properlyâa proposition that `the committee shall present its final report on any matters referred to it on or before . . . the last day of sitting in the year 2000.'

speech.para: That was another weakness in the motion before us, and I think that has been rectified. We do not have a situation at the moment where there is anything formal for the committee to inquire into. There is no way that you can read the now 13-part motion and suggest that that is not the case. We have a situation at the moment where the motion before us is far more appropriate for a standing committee than for a select committee. That is a pretty fair and objective analysis of the situation that we have.

I have to say to the Senate that it is not the opposition's intention to oppose this motion, but it is the opposition's intention to try and ensure that the Senate acts properly in relation to the establishment of select committees. I point outâand I do not know if others in the Senate have given any consideration to this factâthat we have a matter before the chair proposing an eight-person select committee and that two of the members of the select committee will be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. In other words, two out of eight of the committeeâone-quarter of the committeeâwill be Labor senators.

We could mount a persuasive caseâa very persuasive case indeedâto argue for greater representation. I am not going to do that. I am not going to propose an amendment, but I point out to the Senate yet another flaw. In other words, if on the basis of representation in the Senate you are entitled to three out of eight committee members, perhaps someone should argue why on this particular occasion the government has not taken account of that issue.

talk.start.para: âIt's another gerrymander.

âIt is a gerrymander. But I will leave that and go on to another point. This is now the third select committee to be proposed in this parliament. We have a select committee on the new tax system, a select committee on the socioeconomic consequences of the national competition policy and now this proposal before us for a select committee on information technologies. Again, the point needs to be made that the select committee on the new tax system was an initiative of the Australian Democrats; the select committee on the socioeconomic consequences of national competition policy was the initiative of Senator Margetts, representing the Western Australian Greens. Now we have a select committee on information technologies that is the initiative of the government.

speech.para: I make the point at this stage that the opposition has not been successful in propos ing the establishment of a select committee, and I hope that the Senate shows equal generosity when the opposition does bring forward a proposition for the establishment of such a committee. We think there is certainly an entitlement as far as the opposition is concerned in this regard.

So there are some flaws of a technical nature in the motion as it currently stands, which make this quite an unusual motion to be placed before the Senate, and that is really the nature of the concerns that the opposition has with the motion. I am not going to the issues that Senator Brown has gone to in relation to what he believes might be debated, dealt with and referred to this select committee. I do not know what those issues are going to be. If important matters, such as some of those that he was referring to, do come before the select committee, obviously they will be treated as serious ones by the opposition, because we do believe that there are very important public policy implications in the sorts of issues that Senator Brown and others might raise. But at this time I am not in a positionâand I do not think too many senators are in a positionâto second-guess what those issues might be, and that is a flaw in the motion that is before the Senate at this time.

Regardless of that, these are important issues for the government to address; and I hope it does. We do not want to see a chair of a select committee being paid when the committee actually has no work to do. I do not think any senator would want to see that occur. It is important, if we are to have a select committee, that its actually has something to inquire into. I do not think that is unreasonable. There are serious flaws in the motion at the moment. As I have indicated, the motion before us is more in the nature of a motion relating to a standing committee. Perhaps these things will be addressed quickly; I assume that they will be. I hope that this contribution is accepted in the spirit in which it is given, because there is no doubt that we are setting a precedent hereâ

talk.start.para: âIt has always got to be constructive.

âIndeed; I could not agree more with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate in that regard, and let the record stand. Regardless of these concerns, which I hope will be addressed by the government in very short order, the opposition will support the motion.

âI have listened carefully to what Senator Faulkner has said. I have had another look at the motion itself. Arguably, it may be setting up a shell butâas I and others who have been following this for some considerable time understood itâI thought that this was a re-establishment of the previous committee to continue to conduct itsâ
âIt does not say that here.
âThe government should take note of what you have said.
âIt is a sort of a wholesome osmosis problem.

âSenator Brown talked through enormous ignorance when he got up. He was saying that there is nothing for this committee to do. Here is the draft chairman's report ready for us to look at on day one.

speech.para: Senator Brown interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou are ignorantâthrough you, Madam Acting Deputy President. He should not get up and try and mislead the Senate.

speech.para: Senator Brown interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNobody is misled by you. This is the hard work that has been done. It is about evaluating the appropriateness, effectiveness and privacy implications of the existing self-regulatory framework in relation to the information and communications industry, in particular the adequacy of the complaints regime. Is that not something that Senator Brown should be interested in? Of course it is. But no, we have not been doing anything on this committee! This matter of privacyâand consumer protectionâis a very important matter indeed, particularly in this rapidly developing field.
âI am not arguing that it is not important.

âI know you are not. I am referring to Senator Brown's conspiracy theories. Every time he gets up he is on a conspiracy theory. Let us put that to bed. To evaluate the appropriateness, effectiveness and privacy implicationsâ

speech.para: Senator Brown interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou are not interested in that, Senator Brown. You did not even know what we had been doing on this hardworking committee. This matter was referred to us and there were advertisements in January 1998. The committee received a large number of submissions: 47 from organisations and individuals. We had public hearings in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra, again in Sydney and Adelaide, and further meetings in Canberra and in Sydney, hearing from these people. They gave us their evidence. We spent time sifting through the evidence. The chairperson of the committee was Senator Ferris. The draft chairperson's report was ready and something happenedâ
âWhen was it ready?
âThe election happened.
âIt was six months ago.
âWhen was the election?
âIt was 3 October.

âThis has got on it `Confidential Draft Chair's Report 8 October'. I think we met before then and did some work on it. I have certainly been through itâon the privacy area, which is very important. We want to try and get this before the chamber and logged into the chamber as soon as possible. You are going to ask: what has happened between the election and now? The message that we got very clearlyâand that I was getting very clearly from your sideâwas that there were too many committees. Is that not so?

speech.para: Senator Robert Ray interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe question was put to me when Senator Margetts's committee was being proposed as well.
âYou are getting the message from both sides. I can tell you the message that side gave you.

âPerhaps they will. But the message that we and Senator Ferris were getting was that you were saying there were too many committees and this was on the backburnerâafter all the important work that we did on the area of privacy.
âNo-one told us you had a report ready to go.

âWe do. All the good work was done. The people who gave their evidence are wondering what the heck is going on and where the report is. Every honourable senator will realise that. That scotches the conspiracy theory put forward by Senator Brownâthat this committee has been established for me. For crying out loud, I need this committee like a hole in the head at this particular time. But this is a rapidly developing field. You have to have a fairly open remit because it is a rapidly developing field. We have to have a look at the questions of ownership and of consumer protection and at a number of other issues. I give notice to the government, as well as to everybody else, that I think, to clear the air, the proposals that have been put forward by Senator Alston recently ought to be referred to let people have the chance to give open expression to their views. Let them do that. That would be well and truly in the open. Why not do that? I put it to the government and to everybody else around the place: would that not be something that would be useful for this particular committee to do? I make that serious suggestion.

speech.para: I have nothing more to add except to go to Senator Faulkner's point. Having another look at it, I think he may in fact have a point. I should imagine a simple suggestionâand I look to the clerks to advise on the particular matter, but I would certainly like to see thisâis that the committee be re-established as quickly as possible to get on with its job so as to be able to report.

talk.start.para: âYou are going to pay a chairman to do nothing, Brian.
âThe chair has not been doing nothing, I can assure you.
âNo, the chair's not been appointed yet.
âNo, the previous chair, Senator Ferris, has been working vigorously.
âI'm not arguing about that. I'm talking about the new chair. You wouldn't want to appoint a chair and pay them to do nothing.

âNo, let us do something about it now. I know that Senator Ferris and Senator Quirke, the deputy chair, put a lot of work into this. I do not know whether the clerks can give some advice as to what might be necessary to ensure that we can get on with the job of completing this particular report on privacy. And I give fair warning to everybody that, if people think that things have been done behind closed doors, all right, let us have it out in the open. Let us see what merit or otherwise there is in the government's propositions in respect of the net.

âSenator Harradine has referred to a reluctance by the opposition with regard to the number of committees, and in that he is correct. I think in the last count of committees, the total we got to was 47. Our concern is not to stop avenues of exploration in this chamber but merely that, if you create so many committees that senators cannot give them their proper and full attention, they never reflect the proper views of senators. You end up devolving the writing of reports to consultants and committee secretaries and the involvement of senators becomes less and less.

speech.para: We are also being very conscious of the funding decision made by the Department of Finance and Administration and the Senate to put into the base funding of the Senate funding for select committees. You might remember, Senator Harradine, that we had seven select committees in 1995 and that was putting enormous pressure on the resources of this particular chamber. I think that mostly through the drive of the Labor members on the staffing appropriation committee, but certainly assisted by the President, we were able to come up with a formula with DOFA that put funding into our base funding. We have always been careful not to go beyond that and put pressure on other areas of Senate funding.

Therefore we take the view that select committees must have a specific purpose to serve. They are not there just as a convenient substitute for reference committees because someone wants to change the composition of the numbers or get more publicity. We believe most of these referencesâI stress `most'âshould go to the references committees, but there are exceptions. Some specific issues are better served by select committeesâand the areas that are dealt with by Senator Ferris's committee may well fall within that categoryâbut we have been careful and cautious about just how may select committees we set up. One of the easiest political stunts in the world, when you are under a bit of political pressure over a specific issue, is to go back to the particular constituency and say, `I've got it fixed. I'm going to move for the establishment of a select committee.' I would suggest that one or two of the committees that existed in the eighties had their genesis in that.

Senator Faulkner has made the valid point that when you are considering setting up select committees, who around the chamber has a fair chop at it. We know that this committee is being set up by the government at the government's initiative, and I think the government is entitled to a select committee every now and then. We know that the GST committee was set up by the Democrats and we know that the competition policy one was set up by the Greens. That just leaves one set of dancers on the floor without a chairâthe Australian Labor Party. So we just forewarn people and humbly submit that we would expectâunless it is totally outrageousâthat if we come up with a reasonable suggestion for a select committee, maybe when the GST committee has finished its work, we would get some consideration, constituting more than a third of the Senate.

In this case, this committee is being set up with a government chair, and I have to say I think that is reasonable. It is not a matter we would criticise because in terms of select committees there has been a reasonable rotation between government and opposition of select committees, so we have no objection to the government chairing this committee. We have some puzzlement as to why we were allocated two out of eight, rather than three out of eight. That is not usual in these procedures, but we will put two such powerful intellects on this committee that we will easily match the four government ones.

talk.start.para: âWho?
âWe have not made that decision yet, Senator Ferris. We are not quite sure who will serve on it; nevertheless, we are quite sure two Labor people can match four coalition people.

speech.para: I did raise the question: why is this committee being set up now and not immediately after the election? I must say I have not been encouraging people to set up this committee in the view of limiting things. Frankly, I had no idea until Senator Harradine got to his feet today that he had a report ready to goâwhich I suppose is a testament to the fact that Labor members of the committee do not discuss the internal workings of the committee with us and that they have kept their confidence about it. But I did not know that. Clearly, had I known, Senator Harradine, that you had a report ready to go, I would have encouraged the setting up of this committee again in November at least to transact that business and to complete it. I did not know that and therefore that was one of the reasons I have not been enthused about setting the committee up.

When it comes to the question of terms of reference, this is the first time a select committee has ever been moved without terms of reference. That was the nub of our problems with it. This is easily resolved. I encourage Senator Harradine or Senator Ferris to go to the clerks at some stage this morning and develop a reference to finish this last reference. We as the opposition will give you leave not to give a notice of motion but to move an immediate reference to the committee so you can proceed and finish that work. So you can have the reference today, as far as we are concerned, if you can get the terms ready that relate to that previous report.

Senator Faulkner raised the point that that would obviate this problem of having a chair elected and being paid to do nothing. The last time that came up was when Senator Harradine indicated that I was paid to do nothing. Funnily enough, I was the only one to agree with himâhe thought he had hurt my feelingsâbecause at that stage the Privileges Committee had no work. But anyone looking at the number of reports that were brought into the chamber subsequently would realise that, if it had been my intention to take a chair with no work, I was amply punished by this chamber with the many references they sent to the committee.

I agree with the moving by Senator Campbell of a reporting date; every select committee should have a reporting date. But it really is putting the cart before the horse. What we should do is move the next reference to this committeeâobviously there is going to be oneâand then move a reporting date, not put in a reporting date before we know what the next reference is.

Senator Harradine has suggested that a good reference would be the question of Internet pornâto use the abbreviated term. That is an area that needs examination, but I have to say that it needs an examination when people's views in this chamber are not grossly distorted by the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. We must enter into it with a reasonable reference, not with the sort of biased views he put in an answer to a question this week when, by inference, he said that the Labor Party did not care about porn on the Internet. That is a total distortion of the Labor Party view that there are immense technical difficulties. The Senator Alstons of this world, for cheap political points, then make the jumpâbecause you have said there are technical difficultiesâthat in some way you are soft on this issue or that you encourage Internet porn. Nothing could be further from the truth about the Labor Party's position. So if we do have a reference on this particular matter, let it be an objective reference and not a polluted one from the minister for communications in this government.

I have seen coalition members in this chamberâSenator Alston and Senator Parer in particularâabsolutely race to put down the private conversations you might have during a division or in the lobby here. They have done it twice to meâboth times distorting my view. Wouldn't I love to reveal in this chamber some of the discussions between the coalition and the Labor Party in the last three months about this committee, whether it should exist and what its reporting date should be. Senator Campbell would be highly embarrassed if I did, but I am not going to lower myself to that level. But, clearly, coalition senators have told Senator Harradine only part of the story and omitted all the other parts.

What we have come to here is an improved motion with a reporting dateâthat is the first improvement. The second improvement we could make is to develop terms of reference today that at least go as far as resolving the previous matters under consideration by the committee. We in the Labor Party will not use any device in the chamber to prevent that reference being made today. As such, you have then set up a select committee and you have the terms of reference. We will then await future terms of reference to this select committee, which we hope will actually try to come to grips with and solve what is going to be an increasing problem, and not make political brownie points or adopt the distorted, knock down the straw man approach of Senator Alston.

The Labor Party when in government was never censorship free. We did have ratings for films and they were enforceable because of the very nature of cinemas. We then had to struggle with videos because of their wider accessibility to under-age people. But the Internet is a far more worrying area in terms of access. I do not believe in unfettered access but equally I do not believe in censoring generallyâunless it has implications for other peopleâwhat adults view.

Trying to draw those distinctions is going to be very difficult, especially when you are involved in technology that a seven-year-old knows a lot more about than I do, and always will. I do not know about other people in this chamber, but when I want my video recorder programmed it is the niece and nephew who do it, not me. That is the difficulty. That is why this is a unique area. It is not a classic conservative versus liberal view on Internet porn; it is not that, it is a completely different issue. I do not want Senator Alston trying to melt it down to that simplistic level and then abusing people around the edges of it like he did the other day.
The opposition will not oppose this motion. We hope that with a bit of goodwill we can knock it into shape, get it through and get on with the next item of government business as quickly as possible.

talk.start.para: âThe Democrats support the re-establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Information Technologies. People have identified the problems with the motion before us. I was going to suggest an amendment along the lines that Senator Ray has foreshadowed, but I understand that the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has undertaken to come up with a form of words. My suggested amendment would have been to section (1) of that motion and would basically add on `in addition the committee shall look at the receipt and consideration of outstanding reports'âreports from the former committeeâas well as the two relevant terms of reference from the committee in its former life, and they are:

speech.para: (b) evaluate the development of self-regulatory codes in the information industries; and,
(c) monitor the personal, social and economic impact of continuing technological change created by industries and services utilising information technologies.
I understand the minister has a more succinct form of words in relation to those terms of reference that will solve the problem before us today.

Certainly the Democrats concede that there has been a process difficulty todayâthe government has come before us with the motion to continue the work of this committee but has failed to highlight the specific nature of that work, hence the concerns in the chamber that that could lend itself to a committee with no terms of reference, a paid chair with no work to do and the opportunity to broaden those terms of reference or to deal with matters that may not be directly relevant or appropriate.

Senator Ray is correct, as was Senator Harradine: there is an outstanding report from this committee. One of the matters discussed, certainly in the Democrats party room, was whether or not this committee should be continued for the very reason that there was an outstanding report. I certainly informed my colleagues of that fact, without necessarily explaining to them in any particular detail or specificity the nature of the report or what the evidence before us was; nor did I even refer to the chair's draft. So I find it a bit extraordinary that other members or parties in this place were unaware that a committee report was in the process of being finalised.

One of the final reports presented to the last parliament by the chair of the Senate Select Committee on Information Technologies at that time, Senator Ferris, was on the need for the committee in the 39th parliament. The recommendation from the chair on behalf of the committee was the re-establishment of the Senate select committee in this parliament. That was a fairly basic recommendation. Among the reasons given for thatâand I think there were something like 10 pointsâwas for the committee to monitor and complete outstanding reports.

The Democrats support in principle the notion of a separate committee that deals with information technology issues, and those issues alone. I take on board comments from Senator Brown that indeed there is currently a Senate committee that is examining information technologies as one component of its work. However, the Democrats believe that a committee on IT on its own is appropriate. That is why in August 1997, when we had this debate the last time, we were very keen to see terms of reference that specifically highlighted these emerging technologies and their impact on society, our economy, our education system, et cetera.

I and my party had direct involvement in the terms of reference that were finalised for that committee. They are not exactly what we wanted; obviously the finished version was a compromise. Nevertheless, we still maintain that these issues are not being examined in the appropriate level of detail by the Senate or indeed by this federal parliament. So we will continue to push for information technology issues to be considered higher on the agenda.

People have mentioned possible references and possible areas of ongoing or new work for this committee. I will not get into the debate about censorship or civil liberties; my views are already on record both in the form of this committee's work and that of the former committeeâthat is, the community standards committee on utilisation of technologies. My concerns are very much on record in relation to issues of censorship.

Of course members of this committee or members of this chamber are not always going to agree with the terms of reference or some of the areas under discussion. The chair, Senator Ferris, will acknowledge that I have written to her on occasion or spoken to her about some of my concerns with the work pursued by the committee, not for some of the reasons that may have been suggested here today but for very different reasons. The last area that the committee was examining, on self-regulation in relation to privacy, was something I was concerned we were duplicating in terms of the work of another committee, namely the Legal and Constitutional Committee of the Senate.

I also suspect that, on occasions, we have missed the correct definition of information technologies in this place. For the purposes of that committee, which I note is still outstanding, we defined information technology as being the media. So we were looking at privacy in relation to the media. It was not a decision that I necessarily strongly supported. That is not to say that it was not an important committee inquiry, but again we have to be very wary that this committee does not lose the opportunity to address issues directly related to information technology.

I have put on record before, and will again in the debate this morning, some of the areas that the Democrats believe this committee should be looking into. Certainly the terms of reference give us the scope to examine areas when it comes to self-regulation, bearing in mind that is one of the suggested terms of reference. Those areas include the detriments of self-regulation and how governments should undertake development of regulation or self-regulation in these industries. In terms of encryption, the areas include the need for uniform standards, the impacts of encryption on consumer confidence, international encryption standards and the benefits of encryption for the development of future technologies, for example the online transmission of sound recordings.

The international electronic community is another area that we have not begun to even touch on in the context of this committee. What is it? How do we define it and understand what is the electronic economy? What are Australia's various roles in this economy? What are the opportunities for Australia to increase its role in the beneficial aspects of this economy and the educational, employment and entertainment aspects of this economy? Is the information society being dominated? That is a fairly obvious question. How can this domination be addressed to ensure Australian culture is sustained, developed and promoted? What measures should Australia adopt to ensure Australia's participation in the international information society?

Then there is another aspect that we must ensure is not lacking not only in our interpretation of the terms of reference but also in the committee reports and inquiries that we pursue. I am referring to the issue of equity and justice, something that Senator Brown touched upon. That involves access to the information society for Australians, the relative justice for different sectors of the Australian community, the role of government in fostering technology equity and justice, barriers in the information society to access equity and justice, and the role of education in the information society.

A key component of this whole debate must be an examination of our intellectual property laws. That would involve evaluating recent decisions that perhaps identified flaws or outstanding problems in our IP laws, the role of international agreements in Australia's intellectual property laws, the adequacy of existing IP laws in Australia and Australia's international interests. It would also involve looking at the adverse impacts of the introduction of new technology into our community, for example restructuring work, the casualisation of the work force, reinventive competitiveness and redefining work, as well as an examination of information poverty.

So clearly there are broader issues for debate in the context of this committee, and the terms of reference that operated last time do allow for this broader debate. Certainly the Democrats more than anyone want to see this committee not hijacked in a way that focuses on issues that are not directly relevant to IT issues. That is the single qualifying factor we have about supporting this IT committee and its future, that is, that it is not hijacked by interests that are in some way unrelated to information technologies, the information economy and information society.

We are happy with the terms of reference that currently exist. We support this committee's re-establishment on the grounds that they are the terms of reference that will be ongoing. If Senator Campbell is not moving his motion, I will seek leave to move my amendment, but I suspect that the minister's will suffice at this stage. We were concerned with one of the areas of examination in the last committee and, as I say, the Democrats' concerns are on record. But I acknowledge the will of the committee, supported by the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and Senator Harradine.

The Democrats just feel that we have perhaps lost a vital opportunity to actually examine IT issues and not issues that were currently under examination by, say, another committee or not necessarily directly related to the IT industry. We are just hoping that this committee will embark upon some of those more adventurous and interesting areas of information technology, like e-commerce, vilification and defamation laws and intellectual property, as they relate to IT. It is with this thought in mind that we support the re-establishment of this committee. It is on the proviso that Senator Campbell moves an amendment that takes into account the terms of reference from the last committee.

I so move, and seek leave to continue my remarks later.
