talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes the failure of the aged care reforms of the Commonwealth Government to:
(i) provide adequate capital funding for the aged care sector,
(ii) equitably provide access to high quality residential and community-based aged care to older Australians,
(iii) protect the viability of aged care facilities in rural and remote regions, and
(iv) address the wage disparity for nursing staff that exists between the acute and aged care sectors;
(b) notes the failure of the Minister for Health and Aged Care (Dr Wooldridge) to resolve the:
(i) setting of accreditation fees for the Standards and Accreditation Agency,
(ii) provision of growth funding for home and community care services to New South Wales,
(iii) finalisation and release of the new certification instrument,
(iv) numerous anomalies and problems that residents and providers are encountering under the Aged Care Act 1997 ,
(v) release of the initial report of the 2-year review of the Government's aged care reforms, and
(vi) release of the report of the Productivity Commission into nursing home funding, handed to the Government 70 days ago; and
(c) calls on the Minister to enter meaningful dialogue with all sectors of the aged care industry to address concerns about the quality of aged care received by older Australians.

I have brought this general business motion before the Senate today in response to serious concerns raised by residents, providers and employees in the aged care sector about the emerging crisis in the sector. Those concerns, some of which are contained in the motion today, describe a pattern of behaviour on the part of the government in relation to aged care that reveals the government's total inability to come to terms with the problems confronting the sector. Many of the concerns that have been raised with me stem from the so-called government reforms that were rushed through in 1996-97. We are now dealing with the results of the hasty implementation of badly constructed policy amended under strong public pressure. We should not forget that the primary purpose of those government reforms was to slash $480 million from the aged care sector.

There are also now widespread concerns about the inability of the current minister, Minister Bishop, to deal with the many issues that have arisen from that initial rush to reform the sector. It seems that the minister is so intent on avoiding becoming the third minister to lose the job as a result of the government's aged care reforms that she has adopted the strategy of doing as little as possible in the hope that this will minimise the number of mistakes that she will make.

The combination of the government's initial ill-considered rush to slash funding to the sector and introduce changes, followed by a strategy of inaction by the current minister, has left the sector in a highly precarious position. It is important to remember that there are approximately 150,000 people residing in residential aged care facilities and thousands more receiving community based aged care services. The government's policies in this area have the potential to impact directly on the lives of hundreds of thousands of older Australians and indirectly on the lives of many of their relatives. The quality of the care and services provided to older Australians is a matter of vital public importance.

I do not need to dwell on the history of the so-called reform process. The fiasco of the accommodation bonds was graphic proof of the government's hasty and badly constructed response to the capital funding needs of the aged care sector. Who can forget the Prime Minister's total humiliation as he reversed government policy while appearing on A Current Affair? That announcement resulted in the accommodation charges that residents now have to pay. It is not surprising that a hasty backflip to a badly constructed policy has not proved effective in dealing with the issue of capital funding in the aged care sector.

At the recent Senate estimates, the department admitted that the accommodation charge will raise only $84 million in 1998-99 and $112 million in 1999-2000. These amounts are woefully short of the money needed across the aged care sector to improve and upgrade nursing homes and hostels, particularly in the lead-up to the January 2001 deadline for those facilities to gain certification.

A report to be released shortly, I suspect, will show that billions of dollars are needed to meet the capital needs of the sector. Providers have made the valid point that the accommodation charge, in delivering small ongoing amounts, is inappropriate given the large up-front costs required for capital improvement. It is looking increasingly likely that a large number of aged care facilitiesâ135 have currently failed to gain certificationâwill be forced to close their doors in January 2001 because they have simply been unable to raise the funds needed to make improvements to their facilities.

Many of these facilities are operating in rural and remote regions where there are already insufficient aged care services, as identified in the recent audit report on aged care. In many of these areas, there is only one aged care facility. If that closes, people will be forced to leave the area where their families and friends live. Having set the 2001 deadline for accreditation, this government has done nothing to assist providers to meet the standards that will be required.

It is also important to note that, in the recent Senate estimates hearings, the department admitted that providers are under no obligation to spend the amounts raised by the accommodation charge on improving their facilities. Within the industry, there are providers who are using the money so raised by the accommodation charge to meet recurrent expenses. In many cases, the use of the funds for this purpose has been forced on providers because of the $480 million that the government cut from the sector in the 1996-97 budget. They are living on the funds that have supposedly been raised to meet their capital needs. There are a minority of providers who are pocketing the accommodation charge and the Commonwealth concessional resident supplementâdoing nothing to improve the quality of their facilitiesâand they will simply sell their licence when the 2001 deadline arrives.

It is scandalous that the very measure the government introduced to meet the capital needs of the sector, however insufficient, is not guaranteed to go towards those capital needs. The government has not made a compulsory link between the payment of those funds and the direction of those funds towards provision of the capital needs of the sector. As a result of all of the government's changes, the quality of many facilities in the sector has declined. Providers want to upgrade their facilities but simply do not have the funds to do so. Ultimately, aged care residents will suffer because of this government's incompetence. These problems will become acute as the 2001 deadline approaches and facilities close down and services to many areas are restricted.

The government's policy on capital funding arrangements in the sector is just one example of how it rushed into a complex issue and now has no idea how to respond to the problems that it has created. Almost all providers I have spoken to have remarked how they have suffered under the sheer number of changes the sector has endured over the last two years. There was little or no consultation with industry on the potential impact of many of these changes and how they might be best implemented.

As a result of this approach, in the middle of last yearâdays after the proposal to coalesce nursing home subsidies was to be implemented, and following last minute pressure from the industryâthe government agreed not to go ahead with that change. The minister called for a Productivity Commission inquiry into the proposal. Here was another of the flawed reforms announced in 1996-97 being reconsidered under industry pressure and the logic of the argument.
It is interesting that the interim report of the Productivity Commission's inquiry into this issue found:

Under the proposal, the quality of care would adjust up or down to fit the income stream provided by resident charges and the arbitrarily determined national subsidy rate. In the Commission's view, it is inappropriate to treat the quality of care as the residual balancing item.

That is, the quality of care in some states, particularly in Victoria and Tasmania, would suffer markedly as a result of this simplistic approach to the funding of nursing homes. The government is focused purely on the cost of the services it provides, not the quality of care and the quality of services delivered to aged care residents in this country.

Even the Productivity Commission, not known as a particularly radical or necessarily caring organisation, has found that those government reforms would be totally inappropriate because they would downgrade care. That, of course, was only the interim report. I cannot share with the Senate what was contained in the final report of the Productivity Commission to the government because the government has failed to release it. The government, through the Treasurer, has had a copy of that report since 13 January this yearâover 10 weeks agoâand we have not had one word from the government about what recommendations are contained in it, what its response might be or when we might hope to have a copy released publicly. This represents just another uncertainty that has been forced on the sector in dealing with this government. They need to know what is in the Productivity Commission report and they need to know how the government is going to respondâthe industry needs certainty and decisions from this government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you do not have to take the word of the opposition that the government's reforms are bad policy. The current minister's predecessor, Mr Warwick Smith, informed the industry in a letter last year that:
. . . mistakes were made in the policy prescription adopted over our first term in Government.

That letter, sent in the immediate lead-up to the last election, went on to give a series of commitments to the industry to address a number of problems that had become increasingly apparent in the sector. Before discussing some of those commitments I note that, as I understand it, none of them have actually been acted upon by the government. I am not sure whether those commitments met the same fate as Warwick Smith or whether the government does intend, at some stage, to honour them.

The commitments included a promise that, if re-elected, the government would examine ways of providing further capital funding support. The former minister also gave a commitment to make changes to the arrangements for phasing out the previous grants given to providers. These commitments are an admission by the then minister responsible that, as of late last year, the government's solution for funding capital improvements in the aged care sector was not working. Another commitment given by the minister in that letter concerned residents in nursing homes prior to 1 October 1997. That commitment would have guaranteed that this group of residents would not be subject to the accommodation charge should they be forced to move to a new nursing home. This has become an issue where a home closes, or wards are closed, and the residents are forced to transfer to a new facility. As a result, these people are classified as new residents, are caught under the new system and are required to pay the $12 a day accommodation charge.

A number of constituents have written to me and other Labor members of parliament raising their concerns about their treatment in this way. There are approximately 4,000 residents who are potentially affected by this anomaly. At the time the change was introduced, the Prime Minister gave an assurance that existing residents would not be affected by the changed funding arrangements. It seems that this was, again, another non-core promise. Despite the assurance, constituents are writing to me about their parents who were in a home before 1 October 1997 being forced to pay the accommodation charge after their existing home was closed and they were forced to transfer to another home. In some cases, a provider has built a new facility and then transferred all the residents to the new building, enabling them to charge the fee to those residents. I know the government has been aware of this issue for some time, but it has taken no action to protect the interests of those residents affected. It is a clear breach of the Prime Minister's undertaking and it is a clear mistreatment of those aged Australians. The government must act to rectify that problem.

Industry is getting used to delays in decision making by this government. The current minister appears intent on doing as little as possible for as long as possible in the hope that this will increase her chances of surviving the portfolio that has become such a graveyard for Liberal Party ministers. Two ministers have already sacrificed their careers to the government's failed aged care reforms. This minister does not want to become the third. While her strategy might succeed if she had to last only a few months, she surely cannot hope to get through the next three years without making a decision or dealing with the very serious problems that exist in the industry. If she continues to pursue this strategy, aged care will slip further and further into crisis.

Late last year the government put forward a bill that would allow the Standards and Accreditation Agency to charge fees for accrediting facilities. At the time, the government was eager to push the bill through to allow the agency to begin the massive task of accrediting the 3,000 residential aged care facilities before the January 2001 deadline. That bill was passed on 2 December 1998. It is almost four months later and the minister still has not finalised the schedule of fees that has to be tabled in this chamber. The deadline for accreditation was always going to be very tight, but now it is looking increasingly unrealistic. The minister has just wasted four months because she does not seem to be able to make up her mind about how much to charge facilities for accreditation. We are told that at the time the bill was proposed, a draft schedule of fees had already been prepared.

This is not the only issue on which the minister has procrastinated over decisions to the point where the sector suffers. I will mention another few from a very long list. The minister is still to finalise the new certification instrument, which was due to be finalised last September. Until this document is finalised, providers are uncertain as to what standards they should be building to, which is further hampering the improvement of facilities in the sector.

The minister has not released the initial report of the two-year review of the government's aged care reforms. This review will provide valuable information in assessing the impact of the government's reforms. The six-monthly reports of the review should be made public to allow residents, providers and employers to make their own assessments of the success or otherwise of the reforms. The minister has also delayed the provision of growth funding for HACC to New South Wales. These grants should have been finalised late last year, but HACC service providers have been left in limbo because the minister will not sign off on these funds. She has of course attempted to blame the New South Wales government for the delay.

It is difficult to give due consideration to all the issues in aged care in the time available. There are so many problems building in the sector that are not being addressed. My colleagues who will follow in the debate will be addressing some of those, and I appreciate the contributions they are going to make. It is important that this chamber, this parliament and the government start to face up to the very real problems that are emerging as a result of the government's so-called aged care reforms. Every day another problem, another anomaly, emerges from the Aged Care Act. The government seems unwilling to confront those issues, unwilling to take the necessary action to provide leadership and certainty to the industry in resolving those issues.

These problems have the potential to see a decline in the quality of care for many residents and growing inequities in the system. The minister is compounding these problems by failing to address them. The minister is required to provide the leadership to address these issues and bring certainty and coherence to the aged care sector. She seems unwilling to do so at this stage. The longer the minister procrastinates, the worse the problems get, the worse the funding issue will become and the greater the decline in quality and choice available to Australians requiring aged care will become. The minister has shown complete disinterest in working cooperatively with the sector to address the many problems in the system that her government has created.

It is important that we bring these issues to the attention of the government. It is important that the government responds in a positive and constructive way. Unless it does so, we will see a serious decline in the quality of aged care provided in this country.

talk.start.para: âThe motion before us, put by Senator Evans on behalf of the Labor Party, really is a cruel and disparaging attack on the 20 per cent of aged Australians who use aged care services. Senator Evans is opportunistic in the extremeâscaremongering the aged when his efforts would be better placed comforting and alleviating them in retirement. It pays to look carefully at the motion he has put forward and the speech that he just gave, which did not get down to addressing the issues of people or human points of view.

speech.para: Before looking at the details of Senator Evans's motion, we should begin by asking: what are the problems for this current generation of aged Australians? Why, after 13 years of Labor Party rule in federal government, are we now standing here in this place debating a series of very negative points put by Labor which are certainly not in the best interests of the aged? Essentially, those aged 60 and over have inherited the economic legacy of Labor in governmentâthat period from 1983 to 1996. If you were 45 years of age and had a housing mortgage in 1983 when Labor came to government, you certainly would have paid dearly throughout Labor's reign in the form of astronomically high interest ratesâpeaking at around 17 to 18 per cent. So while Labor mauled and abused the economy, who are the people who paid? What generation of Australians felt those effects? These people are now beginning to plan their retirement, as are many others who have moved into the retirement age and have been affected by that generation of Labor's administration.

I find it curious that Senator Evans should find it appropriate to move the motion he has here today, because Senator Evans and his party are directly responsible for undermining the security of aged Australians, and for that they should be condemned. What did 13 years of Labor mismanagement right across the board do to superannuation? What did it do to retirement investments? What did it do to health care? There is no acceptance of responsibility for an entire generation of very important economicsâfor all of these exacerbating problems that Senator Evans would have us believe our aged Australians now face. This motion is hypocritical. It is nothing more than a dot-by-dot reference of Labor's guilt file, attempting to shift their 13 years of mismanagement onto the Howard government.

Three years into the Howard-Fischer government, we are wrestling to address a number of hard issues for the people affectedâfor the aged people of Australia. We have to cover Labor's legacy. We have turned the economy around and we have fortified Australia to such an extent that we have been able to weather the Asian economic crisis and stand in good stead to prosper as a regional leader. We have given back security and cash advantages to families, who now feel it. We have shifted the focus of government back to regional and remote Australia. We will be putting in place a strong, robust tax system designed to meet our national needs. This last point also involves implementation of a workable Commonwealth, state and territory financial arrangement which will see the states better resourced to meet the needs of their aged residents.

I invite Senator Evans and others so critical in this debate to go to the various policy documents of the Liberal-National Party coalition and also of the Labor Party. Take a good look at our document Older Australians under health and family services. Part A refers to tax reform for older Australians. In part B, which refers to carers, we say that we will allocate $80 million over four years to expand community based respite care options for carers of people with dementia. I refer in that particular regard to yesterday's announcement by Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services, of $100 million for Australian carers. The effect of that will be that 14,000 carers of adult relatives will qualify for assistance for the first time, at a cost of $92 million over four years. Under `Residential and aged care', we address the issue in real stark policy terms. We say:

Planning arrangements for aged care places will be reviewed to deliver more flexibility to local communities and better recognise the geographic and demographic realities of rural and regional Australia.

In part D, `Older people living in rural and regional Australia', we say that we will provide rural transaction centres and reinstate and set up better Medicare Ezyclaim facilities by providing additional resources to regional health services. Under our policy, we have instituted the International Year of Older Persons. The other policy issues refer to healthy lifestyles for older Australians and building safer communities for older Australians and older job seekers. They are stark and very worthwhile policy points to look at.

If you turn to the Labor Party document, it is basically a regurgitation of past criticisms and sins and looks at areas which really can reflect on only their own administration. They wrote this a year or two after losing office and they accepted no blame or responsibility for any of the issues. If you turn to the last couple of pages, they come out with a few policies with respect to trying to capitalise on nursing homes issues that were current last year and talking about pension increases, which is always fashionable in an election period.

It is important that we turn now and have a look at those issues that are addressed in Senator Chris Evans's motionâa motion in about eight or 10 parts which is nothing more than a series of dot points on which he has sought to score points. Let us take a look at it. The first point he raised was failure to provide capital funding. What did Labor do? They withdrew capital funding over their period in office. They commissioned and then ignored the Gregory report. All Labor was interested in was to deliberately scare older Australians. I think that is what has come through again in today's debate.

By comparison, Prime Minister Howard's plan to improve the capital flow into the sector is now paying dividends. This week in the Sydney Morning Herald there was evidence that Commonwealth policies are working. There is significant interest by organisations in injecting funds into the aged care industry. The second point raised is with regard to equitable access to care. Labor failed to meet residential care targets that it even set itself. The National Audit Office reported that there was a drop in the number of residential aged care services over the last 10 years of Labor administration, and certainly Labor ignored the bush. Under Labor, there were 16 multipurpose services provided; there are now 42, and another 24 are planned. Under Labor, the safety net for these people was very weak.

We have redressed those inequities between states and regions. We have paid particular attention where it is important, at raising the level of aged care places in particular areas, and we have increased the range of aged care and health services to people living in rural and remote Australia. This government cares about older Australians and cares particularly about their residential care situations and the financial issues that so importantly arise from those areas.

On the issue of viability of aged care facilities in rural and remote regions, again in Labor's period there was nothing but a complex set of confusing funding supplements in nursing homes only. It is important to look at what the government has done. We have extended this supplement to also cover hostels. The viability supplement is targeted at facilities in rural and remote areas with a weighting given to small facilities. Certainly, we make these arrangements with extensive consultation. In particular, rural hostels are now funded for the care needs of their residents and the government has a $10 million capital program. Facilities in rural and remote areas are a special target. That makes a nonsense of the point in Senator Chris Evans's motion.

The fourth point alleged a failure of the Commonwealth government to address the wage disparity issue of nursing staff. The government is still working within the framework set. Labor put in a new indexation method which does not tie the indexation to wage movements that Labor's 1995 decision shifted to safety net adjustments only. The government has removed inefficient bureaucratic barriers to the funding system to enable workplace agreements and improved work practices where staff could share the benefits. The coalition government's reforms have seen an extra $160 million per year for recruitment funding and this has been confirmed by an independent review.

There were a number of issues that Senator Chris Evans related to Minister Bishop, including the setting of accreditation fees. The government has put in place a rigorous process to ensure the best outcomes. The fee is certainly not to be a tax and the rate that will be set will be fair. This will again be done very carefully. We have asked a consultant to work with the accreditation agency to advise on a fee structure that is both fair and equitable.

The principles are being drafted. It is expected that they will be before both houses of parliament shortly after Easter. Under Labor, poor quality nursing homes were allowed to get away with giving poor quality care for too long. We will no longer tolerate poor care for frail older Australians.

Funding for HACC services is important. Sometimes in this area it is very important to look at what is going on, particularly in New South Wales, where there has been a media and correspondence exchange between Minister Bishop and the New South Wales Labor government which has not picked up many of the issues in those areas. Older people and people with disabilities in New South Wales missed out on $15 million worth of HACC funding because the Carr government failed to match the Commonwealth's offer in the first two years of the Carr government. This was a total of over $12.7 million which would have paid for 5.6 million meals on wheels, almost 400,000 hours of community nursing or more than 450,000 hours of home help. By comparison, Victoria has had no trouble meeting the requirements. The Commonwealth spends more than $500 million on home and community care each year to help frail older people, people with disabilities and carers, and we have increased HACC funding by five per cent.

On the issue that Senator Evans raised with regard to certification, we are very concerned about improving the standards of residential care buildings. Labor totally ignored this problem. Contrary to what Senator Evans has alleged in his speech, the new certification instrument was approved on 3 March. It is now being printed and will be sent out after Easter. This will give the industry certainty. The instrument has strong endorsement from industry and consumer groups. Again, the government is setting standards, requiring poor nursing homesâLabor's legacyâto come up to scratch, giving them a strategic 10-year plan and directions and certainty for building and upgrading.

Senator Evans wrongly made the point that additional recurrent funding payments will become certified. Prior to the election, the government undertook to introduce an arrangement whereby service providers could receive capital transition payments for residents living in the home prior to 1 October 1997 and access accommodation payments. On 11 December 1998, Minister Bishop sent a fax to service providers confirming the change. Under the new scheme, nursing homes will be able to be certified and also seek accommodation charges from new residents or concessional supplements in respect of eligible residents. The capital transition payments will taper down over time as the number of new residents increases. The department is currently developing the arrangements to introduce this change. Industry groups are being consulted in the process. Again, where is Senator Evans getting his information?

With regard to the two-year review, it is important to note that a summary of Professor Gray's first six-monthly progress report on the review was released on 18 March, and we have written to the stakeholders to advise them of this. The report is now available from Mrs Bishop and the department. The report details outcomes, particularly as a result of the round of discussions that have been held. Over 500 people with a good knowledge of aged care were consulted in 50 focus groups in 17 locations throughout rural and metropolitan Australia. They certainly identified that the reformâimprovements in standards of care, residents' contributions to the cost of their care according to their ability to pay et ceteraâwas necessary. This gave us a clear message that the industry was very much in need of reform and that it was time the government took actionânot inaction and decline as happened under Labor. The review confirms our commitment to increasing the quality of care for individual older Australians. This is very important.

With regard to the Productivity Commission reports, the commission handed the final report to the Treasurer on 13 January, and this report is due to be released very shortly. There will be a period of consultation and consideration, after which the government will make decisions on the report.

Labor's record was that they were locked in state differences. That remains the case today, because they are obviously locked in their thinking. They had 13 years in which they slashed capital funding, failed to keep pace with the ageing population and failed to take action against poor quality homes. They left behind a funding system for nursing homes which was totally out of date. Labor knew when it was in government that Australia was ageing, and it took no action.

talk.start.para: âThat's not true.

âI am sorry, but your record speaks for itself. You have not been in the chamber listening for long. Labor certainly left aged care in a mess. That particular point is very important. There are, of course, a lot of groups in the community that are in consultation with Minister Bishop and with the government. They are very pleased with the record and with the involvement and the consultations that are taking place. Let me just give you one endorsement from Eldercare, a major religious and charitable provider in South Australia:

speech.para: Few can complain about the changes that have resulted from the process of aged care reform. The outcomes for Eldercare have been significant and we are now in the best financial position we have been in for several years. The new resident classification system is reflecting and funding the resident mix that we have always had but struggled with because the old classification system had long passed its use-by date. Across our 640 nursing home and hostel residents this produces additional government care related subsidies estimated at $2 million per annum. Over 80 per cent of this has been spent on additional staff.

These are clear endorsements of the government's program and policies for aged Australians. We should look at what the real priorities are, what they are being given and what they were not given by Labor during its particular term in office. I note that Senator Evans did not use the total 20 minutes speaking time that was allocated to him. In fact, he fell five minutes short. Again, this is indicative of the priority he gives to such an important area. He ran out of puff on this particular issue. He cannot spare five minutes to add to his own motion on such an important issue. Those aged Australians that Senator Evans claims to represent are, indeed, very poorly represented.

By comparison, Minister Bishop and the Prime Minister have indicated this government's priority in the area of aged care by appointing a very competent administration. Mrs Bishop is in constant contact with all of thess groups within the portfolio and is achieving results. Senator Evans's motion is a pathetic contribution, particularly in this, the International Year of Older Persons. As always, the ALP is looking backwards and not to the future.

talk.start.para: âOver the past couple of years the Democrats have been very careful to distance themselves from much of what the ALP have had to say when it comes to aged care, although I have to admit that the statements that we are concerned about were made mostly in another place. We have had to do this because much of what was said, particularly in relation to controversial issues such as accommodation bonds, we would seriously question. A great many statements made by the opposition over the past couple of years have had the effect of preying on the emotional vulnerability of elderly people in order to score political points. Some statements have, unfortunately, borne little resemblance to the truth.

speech.para: Having said that, on behalf of the Democrats I would like to speak in support of some aspects of the motion which is before the Senate today. I want to make it very clear that I may not agree with everything that opposition senators say in support of this motion. However, I can support many aspects of what is put before us.

The Democrats have long highlighted the desperate need residential aged care facilities have for increased capital funding. What we believe is needed is a policy package which is considered, consistent, coordinated and has some long-term vision. Without this, the future viability of residential aged care in this country simply cannot be guaranteed. Neither the coalition's current aged care package nor the Labor Party's pre-election promise to abolish all nursing home fees and provide a mere $500 million to the sector over three years is going to provide the funding which is so desperately needed.

In 1994 the Gregory report, which was commissioned by the former Labor government, estimated that approximately $1 billion in today's figures was needed just to get the existing nursing home stock up to scratch. The report highlighted the poor physical condition of nursing home infrastructure, including the fact that a number of aged care facilities did not even meet basic fire standards and a number of others were skating very close to the edge.

Despite the government's efforts, little has really happened to change the situation since 1994 and, unless something is done, it is likely only to get worse. Things are likely to get worse, because Australia has a rapidly ageing population. It is predicted that, by the year 2051, 22 per cent of the population will be over 65 years of age and nearly 11 per cent will be over 75 years of age.

The Democrats acknowledge that the coalition has attempted to address the shortfall in funding for residential aged care facilities during its first term in government. It did this initially by introducing a number of reforms, including its controversial nursing home entry fees. The Democrats supported these proposals, because nobody, including the Labor Party, had ever been able to come up with an alternative and because we understood the urgent need the aged care sector had to raise additional capital.

After successfully negotiating with the government a number of added protections for elderly Australians, the Democrats believed we had something we could live with. But I have to say that we were disappointed when the government dumped a great deal of its package after the opposition's huge scare campaign which preyed on the emotional vulnerability of elderly Australians.

When considering this motion, none of us should ever forget that the ALP had 13 years when they were in government to address the problems in residential aged care. But they did not do so in any adequate sense. Now, as a result of the government's backflip on aged care policy, we have ended up with a watered-down, user pays based policy which is a long way short of providing a solution to these problems. While many aged care providers now say they think the current system may provide the capital they require in the long termâthey say perhaps 10 to 15 yearsâit will provide little relief in the short term. I understand that the time the government had initially projected for when all the facilities would have to be up to standard has really had to be extended, simply because the reality is that it will be impossible for all of the aged care facilities to ever meet that standard.

What I want to know is: what is the government going to do to assist facilities in need of upgrading to meet the standards set down for certification in the meantime? I urge the government to consider the possibility of offering these facilities some kind of loan to help them to undertake the work they require. I really cannot see any other way of funding the upgrades which are needed.

The Democrats believe that any future proposals which are designed to change the way the current residential aged care arrangements operate must be carefully weighed up against the impact they will have on elderly people's ability to access high quality residential care and against the long-term financial viability of the sector. These must always be the highest priorities in devising aged care policy.

Protecting the viability of aged care facilities in rural and remote regions is something which is particularly close to my heart and something which was highlighted in the Productivity Commission's interim report, which was released late last year. A few places I have been to discuss these issues, apart from major cities up and down the coast, include Emerald, Jericho and Dalby in Queensland, Wellington and Dubbo in New South Wales, and some towns in Victoria. The issue is always the same: how are towns in these areas to access the funds they need with a much lower revenue base and ability to raise funds, and how are they to get help on a user pays basis from people in their towns? I would be interested to hear whether the government has any strategies for ensuring that aged people in remote areas will be, in the government's own words, `able to grow old in the place where they have spent all of their lives'. That is very important to them.

The Democrats would also like to hear if the government has any plans for addressing the wage disparity for nursing staff that exists between the acute and aged care sectors. This is something which is often raised with us. It is important to note that this disparity is one which is actually getting worse, not better. I think we need to ask ourselves some serious questions about why nursing staff working in the aged care sector are currently so undervalued in comparison to those working in other areas. In fact, in some ways there seems to be almost a stigma attached to nurses who work for any length of time in the aged care sectorâas though, somehow or other, they are not of the same standard as nurses working in other medical facilities.

The Democrats would also like to know when we are going to see a concrete proposal on the level of fees that facilities will have to pay to be accredited. It seems like a long time since we passed the bill to facilitate the charging of fees last year. Surely it is now time to get some hard, cold figures on the table. Not knowing what the accreditation process will cost is causing aged care providers a degree of stress, simply because it makes it difficult for them to plan for the future. I urge the government to tell us what they are doing in relation to this matter.

In relation to funding for HACC services, I want to put on the record that the Democrats strongly support more community based services and programs. We would like to see an immediate boost in funding for the Home and Community Care program. In fact, that is the only way that the government will be able to fulfil its promise, which is to provide for people to be able to stay in their own homes, because people will not be able to do so without the kind of support that Home and Community Care and domiciliary nursing programs are able to give them.

Another problem, which I must declare an interest in because I have a wife who is a registered nurse and works in an aged care institution, is the excessive paperwork associated with the RCS. My wife constantly tells me that she is so busy doing care plans and filling in formsâ

talk.start.para: âAll paper care and no patient care.
âThat is what she tells me, and she would like to get back to some nursing.
âThe ALP introduced it.

âNo, you changed it, Senator Herron, and it has got worse. It was bad under the ALP, but unfortunately it has not improved as the government had promised. The reports I get are that it has got worse. I think that the government do want to solve that problem, but they have not; and we have got to solve it as quickly as possible. That is an issue that I throw out for the government's attention. I do not want to be cynical, but sometimes I do wonder whether the resident classification scale is there to help us get appropriate care at the different levels that are needed or whether it is there sometimes to put a cap on the funding. I am not cynical, I suppose, but I do tend to get a bit cynical when I see what is happening.

speech.para: The Democrats also urge the government to release without delay the two-year review of the aged care reformsâa review which ended in Januaryâand the Productivity Commission's report into nursing home funding, a report which was completed on 13 January. I think I heard the minister give assurances that both of those will be available very shortly, and that is pleasing.

In conclusion, the Democrats firmly believe that any future changes to the current aged care system and any finetuning of the current aged care package must be done in consultation with the aged care sector. Again, let me compliment the minister for describing the consultation process which is taking place. That is absolutely essential. That is the only way to ensure that we finally end up with a system that will work and be sustainable as Australia's population ages.

talk.start.para: âI will open my contribution to the debate on Senator Chris Evans's motion by declaring an interest of 18 years nursing experience and membership of the two colleges of nursing in this country. I know that by the time I have finished the people who follow me are going to say, `There she goes scaremongering. She doesn't know what she is talking about.' I have to say that I do have some knowledge and therefore some right to enter into this debate. Certainly, the contacts that I have are my peers that are still within the profession: they are my sources of information. I can remember what it was like 20 and 30 years ago in the aged care area.
âIt has changed.

âIt changed. My word, it changed for the better. But what is happening now is that it is changing back to what it was before former Senator Giles's report in 1984. You want to have a read of that report. That is the sort of thing that we are heading back to. As we heard last night from Senator Gibbs, in Queensland the Churches of Christ are having a rearrangement of some of their institutions. They are basically getting rid of their enrolled nurses and their assistants in nursing and they will have health care workers and aged-care workers. And what are the qualifications that are required for aged-care workers?
âMaking money for Doug Moran.

âSenator Quirke, I think that your comment may not be totally factual, but it does certainly highlight a number of points. It can be about making money, or it could be about the fact that this government is actually winding back the amount of money available for nursing care. That is what keeps the patients well; it is what keeps their skin whole and entire and without blemishes and keeps their health status good. They are cutting back on that, it would appear; because aged-care workers are cheaper and they also have no need to have qualifications.

speech.para: Let me remind people of what it was like 20 and 30 years ago. This is from the experience of my peers and colleagues in the industry. As registered nurses, they would go to work on an afternoon shift, often on a weekend, to discover that they had one or two new staff who were there as assistants. All of these people had to be shown, on the job, what to do and how to care for the patients. So not only was the registered nursed providing the care but she was also providing the education for the other staff that were with her. On a number of occasions it has happened to my colleagues that the person they were trainingâand the trainee may only last couple of daysâwould tell them that they had answered an ad for a job that morning for an immediate start as a cook or a cleaner, but because somebody had got there before them and had been given the job as the cook or the cleaner, they had been talked into being a care assistant to work with a registered nurse. That is what used to happen. People would wander in off the street and be given a job.

If we move down this path before us that is what will happen. There is no guarantee that a registered nurse or an enrolled nurse or an assistant in nursing will be employed. This is a major concern for anybody who is in the health care industry. This is not just about having the right number of bodies there, this is about the standard of the delivery of care that is given to people in nursing homes. The level of acuteness of patients in nursing homes these days has risen quite significantly.

In the days when I was nursing, anybody who was sick in a nursing home with things such as pneumonia, or who required a blood transfusion or any other acute care, was immediately transferred to the nearest acute hospital. These days, these procedures are being undertaken in nursing homes. I am told by people who are professionals in the area, with expertise, that blood transfusions are quite common and that they are even doing things such as hyperalimentation and dialysis. Nowhere 20 or 30 years ago would they even have considered doing things like that in nursing homes. Those procedures are now being carried out in these institutions. As the number of people with dementia increases in institutions, it becomes much better for the delivery of their care that they be kept in the same institution, in the same environment with the same carers. As I said, the level of acuteness of patients is increasing.

I have spoken to directors of nursing who have told me that they have had patients back in the nursing home some 24 or 48 hours after the patient has had surgery in an acute hospital on the fractured neck of their femur. This requires a high level of care as it is high dependency. Sure, the RCS will accommodate that, but what will not accommodate it is inadequately trained staff. You need more than just one registered nurse and an aged-care worker. You need people with enrolled nurse qualifications and assistant in nursing experience to be able to support and deliver that care.

We were also told by Senator Gibbs last night that the Churches of Christ in Hervey Bay and Maryborough are saying that the registered nurses will not be expected to take a lead role. I am wondering where we are going in terms of the legal responsibilities here and in terms of negligence. There is a duty of care owed to residents, and that duty of care is expected to be carried out by the average registered nurse or the average enrolled nurse or the average assistant in nursing. We do not know what the standards are for the average aged-care worker. It will not be the parliament that decides what the standards are; it will be a court of law that decides. The court of law will decide that the owner or the proprietor or the manager of that nursing home has a duty of care.

If something happens, and they are found derelict in that duty, they will be two parts down the path to being negligent. If there is damage to the patient, and if there is a direct cause of that damage, the nursing home will be negligent and so too could be the person who has provided that care if they have not been adequately trained. If the people providing the care have not got adequate training that is not an excuse. It will be judged and the people in the witness box will be expert witnesses who will be attesting to what should be the average quality of care that is provided to patients.

I warn people to think very carefully about this and I warn the government, because I think the government has left some loopholes in its legislation. The booklet it put out last year said that `the care may be carried out by a registered nurse'. I warn people to be very careful because there are legal ramifications in all of this. If the employer, the owner, is not providing adequately trained staff, they will be held negligent. We will find that out when we end up in coroners courts. If you are not going to have adequately trained staff, as we see is going to happen in Hervey Bay and Maryborough, you will end up with people in coroners courts, and that is a sad indictment.

The other thing that people need to remember is that we are 20 or 30 years on with improvements in nursing homes and aged care. The community is a lot more litigious now than it was 20 or 30 years ago, so take that as a warning. I am gravely concerned about these changes and this erosion of the standard of care that is being delivered to patients. When all else fails, the standard of care for patients has to be the primary consideration.

This change being mooted by the Churches of Christ is putting in danger, or destroying, the career paths for a number of enrolled nurses in particular. More and more these days, because of the increasing technology and the increasing complexity that is required in the provision of health careâ

talk.start.para: âFour people took voluntary retirement and the others were transferred.

âSenator Herron, you know as well as I about the need to maintain our practice standards so that we can maintain registration. These people will lose their rights to practice and their licence to practice. As with your profession, nurses are now having to keep their practice current. I would not be able to go back and practice in a hospital.

âOn a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: undoubtedly Senator Herronâas a surgeonâis envious of nurses speaking out about conditions in hospitals, but he has been a persistent interjector during the course of this speech. He has an opportunity to be heard in this chamber and to be accorded the respect of being heard in silence. He is a responsible minister and knows that he is out of order by interjecting. I would ask you to advise him as a minister to be quiet and hear the contribution of Senator West.

âOn the point of order: I hold nurses in the very highest regard; in fact six of my daughters did nursing. I have a very high regard for every nurse in Australia for the vocation that they hold. However, I respect Senator Cook's point of order and I will keep quiet.
âI thank all senators. Let us try and enable that to continue throughout the remainder of the debate.

âThank you. I am glad that Senator Herron did interject because that just raises concerns with me about the fact that I thought that he, of all people, would have understood the need to have highly qualified and specialised nurses in the area that he works in, which is surgeryâjust the same as people in aged care deserve the same levels of care. This is the introductionâthe first signs that we are seeingâof the downgrading in the mind of this government of the standing of those who provide aged care in this country.

speech.para: This government is to be condemned for the attempted downgrading of the qualifications of people providing care. Allowing that to happen is appalling, and I have actually warned in the past that that could potentially happen through this legislation. Now we are seeing it happen, so I have been vindicated on that particular point. It is a disgusting thing; it shows a lack of care but it probably relates to the fact that these institutions are not getting adequate funding from the government because there is so much paperwork to be done. They are not getting adequate funding to undertake all of this, and this is the only way that the proprietors of nursing homes are actually able to cope.

The other area that I would like to touch on is the preliminary work that is being done by the New South Wales Nurses Association. It is a study that is unpublished at this stage, and it is going to be done over two years. But we certainly have evidence that they have been able to provide me with that indicates that the impact since the introduction of this act has been quite marked on institutions and aged care facilities.

Nursing groups have been told by the government that aged care funding will increase by 10 per cent. But this survey indicatesâas I said, it is unpublished and it is preliminaryâthat only 4.5 per cent of the respondents believed personal care and nursing hours had increased as a result of new funding arrangements introduced under the act and that 42.5 per cent believed the new funding arrangements had led to reduced hours and changes in skill mixes. The information that has been received in this ongoing survey reveals that more than 40 per cent of aged care nurses have noted an increase in requests to perform work not directly related to care over the last 12 months. More than a third of respondents noted a reduction in the number of registered nurses employed in their particular facility over the same period of time and 32 per cent said there had been a reduction in the number of enrolled nurses. This bears out what is happening in another state.

More than half the respondents said there had been a reduction in the standard of care and 59 per cent noted a reduction in the number of overall care hours over the last year. That probably bears out Senator Woodley's point about his wife's experience of spending more time on doing paperwork than on doing nursing care. Fifty-six per cent believed they did not have the resources necessary to enable them to provide an acceptable standard of nursing care. Almost two-thirds claimed their workload had increased significantly over the last 12 months. Almost 40 per cent believed current staffing levels placed the occupational health and safety of nursing staff at risk. One-third of staffers claimed the risk had increased significantly.

You are going to see that blow out even more if you do not have properly trained staff. People coming in off the street will not know how to lift properly, how to manoeuvre the machines that are used for lifting or how to use the equipment and will therefore be a greater risk to themselves and to the patient. This is just the sort of thing this government said would not happen, and it is now becoming quite evident that it is happening. The nurses are also saying that they are undertaking increased unpaid overtime.

We have also had the story of a hostel being left understaffed. When a woman went to visit her mother there, she and other visitors actually ended up having to support the nurse that was on duty because she was feeling so stressed by the level of workload that had been placed upon her shoulders. Another person in the same place complained because her mother had been left stark naked for 45 minutes because somebody had been called away. These are all examples of the provision of poor care to patients, and I think that the government has to stand condemned. It was warned that these things would happen but it has chosen to ignore that warning and this is now happening.

I also have concerns about what is happening in rural areas because I am being told more and more by institutions in those areas that if they are small their viability is really in danger. There is also an anomaly in the Aged Care Act, which is affecting people in rural areas. I notice that there is an adviser in the box. I presume that the adviser has seen the letter from Ms Sue Irvine from Southern Cross Homes in Broken Hill, because it is in the article that has appeared in the Barrier Daily Truth of Friday, 12 March. It is an anomaly where a resident owns a home and has total assetsâincluding the homeâbelow $23,500.

Before people tell me that that is not possible, I suggest they go and visit Broken Hill, where in the last few weeks the city has been told that the mine will close in a couple of years and there is a number of very small old miners' cottages for sale at very low prices. But, if a person does not have a home and has assets below this amount, they are considered concessional and get $12 a day. People who have assets below $23,500, and that includes their own home, are not classified concessional. This is an anomaly. When it comes to trying to claim hardship provisions they cannot do it. The government needs to fix itâno bleating from anybody. This is something about which an aged care provider has been writing to the department and to the minister for some considerable time.

If a resident has total assets including the family home of less than $23,500 they cannot be considered concessional. The department advises that residents with total assets of less than $37,000 can apply for hardship provisions. However, if a resident has less than $23,500 they cannot be charged an accommodation charge. But, she has been told that the department cannot consider a hardship application if a facility has not charged an accommodation charge.

There is a wonderful little loophole and you have done nothing about it. This particular person, Mrs Irvine, has been writing to the minister for some time about this issue and nothing has happened. It is another area where this government is disadvantaging people living in rural areas, particularly those who are elderly.

The other concern that elderly and rural people may have is the cost of accreditation for small nursing homes and small hostels. The amount of paperwork required is very similar no matter what the size of the institution, but there is nothing there. The other question I would like to touch on is the length of time an institution that has failed certification is given before it is required to actually close its doors. I know of one that was failed last year and the patients are still there. They have been told that they might be moved out of the nursing home some time this year. It is a good question.

I see that my previous comment about loopholes and anomalies has prompted some action on behalf of the departmental officer in the advisers box. Maybe that has been fixed in the last week. Wouldn't that be wonderful?

talk.start.para: âToday we are having a rerun of the same motion that was debated in this place three times, from memory, in 1997. I suppose we can expect it to be rerun many more times by the Labor opposition. The interesting thing about all of these debates is that the Labor opposition never once refer to their record in government. I am sorry for them, because I am going to refer to it tonight.
âThat is not going to help the patients there now.

âSenator West, you certainly did not help the patients when you were in government. I think it is somewhat hypocritical of an opposition to come in here, having cut aged care spending to smithereens in government, and abuse a government that has reversed those cuts and imply that those cuts have not been reversed. Labor withdrew funding enormously. In 1992 there was a total of $45 million spent on capital stock. I notice that Senator West never, ever stays in the chamber for these debates. She does not like to hear this. Senator West, you are Deputy President of this place and you are wanting to interject from out of your chair and talk to me.
âI am sorry, I am not talking to you.
âShe is talking to me about a personal matter.

âIt is just extraordinary. The issue that needs to be raised here is the funding level under Labor. In 1992-93 Labor spent $45 million on capital stock. In 1993-94 that had declined to $26.5 million. In 1994-95 it was down to $15.7 million. In 1995-96 it was down to $10.7 million. That just happens to represent a funding reduction

speech.para: of 75 per cent. I did not hear Senator West or Senator Evans mention that. I seek leave of the Senateâand I have spoken to the opposition about thisâto have a table incorporated in the Hansard which will show Labor's record and the coalition's spending proposals as they stand.
Leave granted.
The table read as followsâ

talk.start.para: âThank you. The other thing I want to make sure is understood in the context of this debate is the fact that, in contrast to that enormous cut, the new capital funding arrangements put in place by Prime Minister Howard in 1997 will provide the $1.3 billion over 10 years that was identified as necessary by Professor Gregory's report and an extra $10 million every year in capital grants in addition to higher recurrent funding. We also recognise that a minority of providers need assistance in meeting the new government requirements for quality building and services. For them we have allocated an additional $20 million to help them restructure and to obtain expert advice on how to do it. Yet we have heard today, again, the Labor opposition saying that we have cut funding.

speech.para: I want to come to that last point that I mentioned about the minority of providers who need assistance in meeting the govern ment's new requirements for quality buildings and services. This is part of Labor's other record. When they left office after 13 years, we just happened to find in the Gregory report that 11 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire standards and 15 per cent did not meet health regulations. Professor Gregory also found that 40 per cent of residents had to share a room of more than four beds. Did the Labor government do anything about it? No, that is the legacy they left. Yet today they
have the audacity to come in here and say, when we are allocating more funding to correct their legacy, that that is somehow wrong and improper.
I seek leave to incorporate another table, which goes to the point of how much funding was cut. Once again I have previously sought the approval of the opposition to do so.
Leave granted.
The table read as followsâ

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party also ignored the Gregory report, yet it was a report that they commissioned. I cannot understand why they would want to commission it and then just let it gather dust. It took the coalition government to come into office and to start reversing the things that had been identified in the Gregory report. All Labor have been interested in doing since is scaring older people.

speech.para: The Labor Party today have clearly said that they do not understand or accept the reality of extra money that has been put in to meet residential care targets. The Australian National Audit Office reported that there had been a large drop in the number of residential aged care services over the last 10 years of Labor. This government has put in $280 million for staying at home packages, and that will raise the level of aged care places to 103 places per 1,000 people aged 70 and over by 2002. That is demonstrated by the first graph that I sought leave to have incorporated tonight.

The other thing that that money does is ensure important things such as more respite care and more carer support. I would have thought, even though this opposition can only knock, that they would say that that was a desirable outcome. But, no, every single thing without exception that the coalition government puts up, they knock. They say it is not good enough. It does not matter how much it is reversing the damage that they did to any given industry in their 13 years of government.

The ANAO report says that considerable progress has been made to remedy the inequities between states and between regions, and that the government's staying at home initiative paid particular attention to rural regions. We just heard a diatribe from Senator West that was purely and simply unbelievable. The ANAO noted that there were still regional inequities, especially in the bush. Labor ignored that; we have started to redress that problem.

The Commonwealth government is committed to reducing these inequities. For example, 30 per cent of the 500 extra staying at home packages allocated in June 1998 went to rural and remote localities. Not one of us would ever say that we would not want more. Of course we would want more. If we lived in an ideal world we would want everything, and we would want to not pay any taxes to get it. But the reality is that the Labor government ran it down and the coalition government has allocated the money in successive budgets to fix it.

As well as that, the government has increased the rate of growth of multipurpose services to provide an increased range of aged care and health services to people living in rural and remote areas in Australia. Under Labor there were 16 multipurpose services; under the coalition government there are now 42 sites, with a further 24 planned. Yet we have had the scare campaign again today that there are inadequate numbers. Why don't they own up and say, `We had insufficient and at least you are turning this around. At least you are doing the right thing and the trend lines are going in the right direction'? There is no recognition at all because they can only knock.

The multipurpose services recurrent funding rates under this government have increased by an average of 10.2 per cent to a total of $17.48 million. Yet the Labor opposition say that they have been reduced. Senator West happened to mention the problems that Ms Irvine had identified. I would like to inform Senator West, had she bothered to stay in the chamber, that Ms Irvine met with the minister yesterday and her concerns are under active consideration by the minister. Of course, Senator West does not bother to stay and listen to the other senators' contributions.

They talk about wage disparity. The government is still working within the framework set by Labor in the 1995 budget. If they think the wage disparity is so bad, why did they not change it? Why have they left it to the coalition government to make reforms that have seen an extra $160 million a year in extra recurrent funding that has been confirmed by an independent review? Why did they not do something about it in government? They come in here, three years down the track, and carp.

It is the same with the accreditation fees. This government is actually doing something about quality. I mentioned the state of nursing home stock at the time of this government's election, which Labor had left in a dreadful state. Under Labor, poor quality nursing homes were allowed to get away with giving poor quality for too long.

Then you get the crocodile tears of Senator West in here today; absolutely breathtaking stuff. But we will no longer tolerate the poor care for frail older Australians. The Aged Care Standards Agency set up by this government will play an important role in improving the quality of care. That is a responsibility of each and every government, but it has taken a coalition government to do it, and I am proud of that.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being six o'clock, the time for the consideration of general business has expired. The Senate will proceed to the consideration of government documents.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Cook:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak briefly on this particular document. My colleague Senator Cook spoke about this yesterday and drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that our relations with India were strained as a result of the tests that occurred earlier last year in India and also in Pakistan. One has to look at the work of the Australia-India Council as being important in the sense that it is a bridge building organisation in the relations between Australia and India. There are other such councils as well for Japan and similar places. This report is indeed welcome because it highlights the work of that particular council over the 1997-98 period.

speech.para: There are a number of things I want to look at in terms of the report. The first is the matter of education. The report says that the objective of the council's education program is to raise the level of knowledge of India, including Australia's relations with India, at the primary and secondary levels in Australian schools. Of course, this also works the other way within India. One of the problems in many of our relationships with other nations is that we do not understand their social, cultural, economic or political systems. Organisations such as this go a long way to overcoming some of those problems. It is interesting to see the program outlined in the report where the council funded a tour of India by Australian primary and secondary teachers during January of 1998 and, according to the report, promoted effective use of India curriculum packages throughout Australia. That is an important element of these types of councils, and it seems from this report that the function is being well performed.

The other issue raised is international relations. My colleague Senator Cook, when he spoke to this report yesterday, referred to the strained relations as a result of the nuclear testing. Senator Cook also referred to the fact that the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee has conducted an inquiry into those tests and pointed out to the Senate that there was a totally bipartisan attitude in this country to the tests that had been conducted in India and Pakistan, and that was one of condemnation. The issue that was raised during the inquiry conducted by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee was how long our protest would remain and how we would go about repairing any damage that was done to the relationship during that period of time. The curious part is that during that period, when our political relations were strained, our sporting relations were certainly not strained, because we had a tour going on in that particular country.

It is important that Australia look at repairing its relations with India, and with Pakistan for that matter. That is something that has not been given any real focus. India will be important to Australia in the future in terms of trade. Last year India was ranked 12th on the list of countries that we export to. We have seen our exports to India grow by 17 per cent, which is a fairly strong trend growth coming off a very low base. (Time expired)

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 March 1999, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

talk.start.para: âThis vital report talks about Australian industry in respect of digital broadcasting and has a most apt title: Thinking outside the box . It talks about the new opportunities that are becoming available for Australians and the approach for the future in the view of some thinkers. Page 36 of the report, appendix C, is headed `Further details and opportunities for Australian industry' and talks about data broadcasting and how broadcasters have a significant advantage `in broadcasting at high speed, independent of the telcos'. I think of data broadcasting as push technology. On the subject of datacasting business applications, it says:

speech.para: The broadcaster pushes information at the consumers, whereas the Internet, which is more of a pull technology, depends on consumer requests for information.
It continues:
Digital television provides broadcasters and datacasters with many business opportunities that were once only in the domain of telecommunications carriers.

This new technology presents people with greater opportunities to get their message out in this age of information technology advances and enables people to push information and to push business opportunities onto people rather than the present situation where, according to this report, people can choose when they are going to have this information put upon them.

This new technology has not only an economic dimension but also a social one. It is incumbent upon us as a parliament to consider now the sorts of policies that we want to have in place so that when this technology becomes an everyday part of our lives, as a nation we will be able to use it in the most socially efficient, the most economically efficient and the most culturally efficient ways. By `efficient', I mean the quality that best serves us as a nation of people who think well and who are benign but nevertheless dedicatedâas we should be in a decent society.

This report points to the necessity for us in this new age of technology to think about the sorts of policies that we should now be adopting to accommodate the future, and I am not sure that we have done that as well as we should. This report, which deserves to be read, will enable us to see the issues that are involved, because it is only when we see the issues that are involved in the future that we can make policies now to accommodate in the best possible way the sort of society we are going to live in, as changed by new technology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
