subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 22 March 1999, on motion by Senator McGauran:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI was a member of the committee that produced the very important report Island to islands: Communications with Australia's external territories , which is the result of an undertaking to look at the communications needs of our external territories, particularly Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. I was unable to make the trip to Norfolk Island, but I made the trip to Christmas and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. There are a number of issues that need to be looked at very carefully because, although they are part of Australia, in terms of communication they are quite remote. The islands are not entitled to any funding, under the infrastructure funding programs, from the sale of the first tranche of Telstra, and their access to lines for the Internet are impossibly slowâthey are basically non-existent. This is a major problem for people, particularly in the education area when schools need to talk to the department in Perth via the Internet. As are most states, Western Australia is moving more and more to the use of technology for the provision of in-service training, for sending out forms and things like that, and their Internet service is not adequate enough to be able to undertake this. It is a big problem and it is one that we have to recognise, although they do have Intranet within the schools and that provides a very good service for them,

speech.para: There are problems also with the air services to the area. They now have some additional flights coming in through Indonesia into Christmas Island but not to Cocos (Keel ing). All of the three islandsâNorfolk, Christmas and Cocos (Keeling)âhave problems with the lack of freight capacity and the off-loading of freight, particularly in relation to health and medical supplies. These sometimes require a cold chainâthey are time sensitive. Certainly we had evidence of specimens being taken from Norfolk Island, sent to Sydney, not being collected properly by the couriers in Sydney and coming back to the island maybe a week later.

The diagnoses of some diseases and complaintsâand also changes in medication, if that is requiredâand the tests that have to be done in Sydney or Brisbane can be time critical. This can delay people's treatment and cause a problem. It lowers their quality of life and it may even endanger their lives. So that is a major problem.

The other crazy thing concerns airmail sent from overseas to Australia to go to Norfolk Island. Let us say it is coming from the US: it travels from the US to Sydney via airmail and it might then be put on slow mail to get to Norfolk. So that anomaly needs to be addressed. One of the recommendations is that, if something is airmailed into Australia, we should not just consider that the airmail component applies only until it reaches the continent of Australia. Certainly a lot of mail gets sent around Australia by air that is not airmail. I think we need to make sure that people are in fact able to obtain this material.

There is also a problem in that many things get off-loaded. It is a bigger problem, I think, on Christmas and Cocos islandsâand I think they have fewer shipping connections than Norfolk as well. We certainly had evidence from a number of people in the Indian Ocean territories that they would know when their telephone bill was due because the telephone would be cut off because they had not paid it. The bill would have been in the mail but would have been off-loaded because the flight was over capacity in weight. The aircraft have to run with additional fuel because it is a long distance to fly out there, and on some occasions that requires them taking less cargo than if the aircraft were doing a run within the country. So it is certainly a concern.

On occasions it also impacts on the availability of fresh fruit and vegetables that might have to come across on those flights. The health people also advised that they had had occasions when urgently needed medications and drugs had been off-loaded because of weight problems. Getting a seat on the aircraft out of Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands going to Perth at peak times can be a problem because the flights can be fully booked for four or five months in advance. That is a major problem if somebody suddenly needs to go to Perth for medical reasons. It means that somebody who would have had their seat booked for some considerable time gets pulled off the flight. This is not good for those who need to travel and it is not particularly good for those who need to be evacuated.

We also heard how telemedicine would be able to improve diagnoses and specialist medical treatment and care, and maybe reduce the need for medical evacuations on some occasions. Medical evacuations are horrifically expensiveâwe are talking big, five-figure sums of money as well as considerable time. If they had sufficient line capacity and electronic capacity, they would be able to look quite realistically at the use of telemedicine and also at being able to send down the line things like X-rays and ECGs so that diagnoses could be made by a specialist, or a consultation could be had with a specialist, in Perth. This may result in, perhaps, not requiring an evacuation or maybe requiring an evacuation earlier than would have been undertaken. It would certainly allow the doctors on the islands to instigate more refined forms of treatment at an earlier stage. So it is a major issue for people in the area.

The change of footprint for some of the television stations was also of concern to them. Digital versus analog is an issue, and even the communications between the two main islands in the Cocos (Keeling) group are very difficult. The reception often does not work. Trying to ring from West Island to Home Island can be difficult. Also, the telephone service does not work on part of Christmas Island. Their television and radio reception is also very much subject to the vagaries of the weather; if there is a lot of cloud cover, this can impact quite seriously upon the ability to receive clear signals.

These are things of concern. We need to remember that Australia is not just this continent and Tasmania; it does include Macquarie Island, territories in the Antarctic, Norfolk Island and the Indian Ocean territories. Whilst there may not be a great number of people living there, we need to make sure that their needs are recognised. Those outlying territories are certainly of strategic importance to this country. We are a multicultural country and we need to recognise that it is important for our islands that are more remote from the mainland to have access to the same programs that we have here on the mainland so that they do not feel isolated and so that they can see and understand what people on the mainland are doing, perhaps why they are doing it and what is going on here. Those islands are of strategic importance to Australia, and I think this report certainly highlights some of the things that need to be done to improve the communications. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 22 March 1999, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak to this report by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties as a former member of this committee. When a lot of the issues relating to the Multilateral Agreement on Investment were being dealt with, there was a high degree of public interest from individual members of the public right through to local government and a whole range of other NGOs with regard to what was proposed for a multilateral agreement on investment and what it meant for Australia.

speech.para: I have not read this report in total but, given its recommendations and the responses from the government to the interim report that was handed down, I found interesting the government's response to two of the recom mendations contained in the interim report. In effect, they say that we have withdrawn from negotiations on the MAI on the basis of the decision by the French government to withdraw. I found that an outstanding position. It does not clarify whether, if the French go back in at some point in time, we go back. There is no indication of that whatsoever.

Given all the problems that were raised at several hearings we had, it became abundantly clear that Treasuryâwhich was the department primarily responsible for dealing with the Multilateral Agreement on Investmentâhad not conducted the consultative process in any way like it should have been conducted. They said, I think, that they had conducted consultations with umbrella organisations, but the information had clearly not flowed and they had not sought to follow it up. It appeared, as is stated in this 18th report, that Treasury felt they owned it. I found the conclusions and the recommendations at page 105 of the report interesting. Recommendation 8.47 says:
The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties recommends that, if there are negotiations for an across countries agreement for the regulation of international capital:
. the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet assume the lead role in coordinating the Australian Government's negotiations;
. the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet actively and effectively involve all relevant Commonwealth agencies from the beginning of any negotiations;

. the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet ensure that all Australians have the opportunity to put their views on all aspects of any negotiating text as part of an open and public process, and

. from the beginning of any negotiations towards such an agreement, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet forward written reports on a six-monthly basis to the Commonwealth about their content and progress.

The committee concluded that simply because of the things that were involved with a multilateral agreement on investment. We had to provide treatment to foreign companies and foreign investors equal to that applied to national companies and investors, and a whole raft of problems could flow from that. The compensation provisions of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment could allow for private companies to actually sue governmentsâlocal governments, state governments and/or the national government. As it was proposed in the draft formâwhere it had got to prior to us withdrawing from negotiationsâyou could actually see us having to repeal democratically made governmental decisions to comply with an international agreement. That is not a position any government or country should allow itself to be put into.

We have been debating in this chamberâand will debate again in this chamberâthe full privatisation of Telstra. What I found very interesting in the draft agreement was where telecommunications was placed. There were schedules attached to this agreement, and telecommunications was placed in the section that had the roll-back provisions applied to it. The roll-back provisions under the then draft multilateral agreement on investment required a country to remove any restriction on foreign ownership of companies, be they public or private.

Despite the claims of the government at the time that they were going to legislate for only up to, I think, 35 per cent or a maximum of five per cent in any single holding of foreign ownership, if we had signed off on a multilateral agreement on investment we could have found ourselves being required to roll back that legislative restriction that we had in placeâto remove it over timeâto allow for the possibility of 100 per cent foreign ownership of Telstra. That is the reality of where we were heading to under the progress of the multilateral agreement that was being negotiated.

Of course, the other thing is that it could have possibly led to the elimination of the Foreign Investment Review Board, which is there, supposedly, to make an assessment of what is in the national interest with regard to foreign investment in this country. It would seek to lock in a whole range of deregulatory measures, such as the one I spoke about with regard to the roll-back provisions and stand-still provisions. I was reading what is a critical analysis by Mr Graham Dunkley. I will read some of the words from that analy sis because I think he has very succinctly outlined some of the concerns and some of the arguments that ought to be put. He says:
Finally, the ultimate argument for the MAI is that FDIâ
which is foreign direct investmentâ
is good, TNCsâ
which is transnational companiesâ

are good, globalization is good; perhaps even greed is good. The traditional arguments for FDI are that it will supplement savings, expand investment, boost GDP growth, generate exports, create jobs, bring new technologies, improve skills and generally enhance innovation.

There is now a vast literature on these issues and the results are not as clear as MAI supporters assume. Certainly FDI can bolster savings, investment and income, but only if new investment continues to out-weight profit repatriations. Exports may only be generated if TNCs choose to make the country an export platform. The balance of payments will only be improved if exports are generated, counter-imports are not too high, adverse transfer pricing is not used and capital is imported (rather than simply raised locally as the new foreign private owners of Australia's airports have done).

I think that is a very valid point because, if we are about negotiating an agreement, then we ought to be negotiating on the basis of what is in the national interest. The negotiators we had under Treasury, who were gung-ho about this, were clearly not taking into account the sorts of circumstances that have been highlighted by Mr Dunkley.

I think the government still owes this parliament and the people of Australia a better explanation and a better response than it has thus provided with respect to where it was headed. It is all very good for some government senators to say, `Look, you started it.' You happen to be in government now.

talk.start.para: âThey have been there for three years.

âAs Senator West just pointed out, you have been there for three years. You have a responsibility to tell the Australian public where you are heading. I cannot for the life of me understand the response that says, `Look, the French have withdrawn, so we're out.' It just beggars belief. What does that mean? When the French have jumped back in, will we be back in? I would be very interested to hear from the government to find out whether or not we will be back in if the French are back in. I think it is a disgrace and I look forward to the government's response to this, the final report on the MAI, and seeing where we are headed. (Time expired)

âMany of the matters I was going to raise have been raised by Senator Murphy in his excellent speech. The committee that was looking at thisâan international committee of the OECDâhas now broken up. That does not mean that we have to cease to be concerned about the flow of international capital. As you would know much better than I, Mr Acting Deputy President, this is what the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, which produced this report, was looking at. It is an excellent committee. It was looking at what the Australian Treasury was doing with other like bodies around the world within the OECD. What they were doing was working out the rules or the absence of rules that should operate in respect of capital as it went international, how it could be transferred, and so on.

speech.para: The report of the committee says that should another institution arise, should another treaty be contemplated regulating the flow of capital around the world, then Australia should be in the body that looks at that issue. And so it should be because the issue of the flow of capital around the world is a big one, as has been very much indicated in recent times with the disasters that have occurred in Asian nations and elsewhere.

If we are going to look at the flow of international capital around the world, we should be in a position to know exactly what capital is doing and how industry in our own country has been affected by the flow of money. There is some concern that we are going ahead with policy making without being fully aware of all the implications that come from the flow of capital and come from the issue of what companies might charge, for example. Prices that are charged and paid affect the flow of capital. In that context, it is interesting to look at the recent publication of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission entitled Telecommunications Charges in Australia. I was reminded of this by the remarks that Senator Murphy made about Telstra. It is interesting to see what the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has to say about current pricing information. It says:

There is no official, published collection of telecommunications prices in Australia. However, Telstra is required to file its tariffs with the Commission and the compliance conditions under the price cap also require it to apply a methodology for estimating and reporting price changes to the Commission. Consequently, the Commission holds a full set of prices of Telstra's services and equipment, and interpretive data in respect of most of Telstra's price-capped services.

The Government has indicated its intention to legislate to require telecommunications carriers to report price and volume data across a range of specified services to the Commission to allow it to provide regular, impartial, public reports of pricing and market share.

It is good to see the government entering into the business world and to bring into it certain regulations and requirements so that the business world can function and operate to the good of the community generally and provide information that is needed to set up a policy, first of all nationally but ultimately internationally, that will enable the riches of the worldâwhich is what capital really isâto be used in the most productive manner. It is a matter of some amazement, I suggest, that we have not got available to us at this stage the sort of information that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission says we should have.

I want to make these points. Firstly, the Multilateral Agreement on Investment is not going to come into operation because the people that were discussing itâpeople from various countries around the world, including Australia, all within the OECDâhave ceased to discuss it. The proposed Multilateral Agreement on Investment is finished. Secondly, it indicates that there is a need and an appetite for some international agreement about the flow of capital. Thirdly, it is likely that there will be a return to a discussion about how international capital should be treated by the various countries around the world.

Fourthly, if you look at the sorts of comments that are made in this report by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, it is essential that there be some requirement that such issues as the prices that are charged and the market share that particular companies have be looked at by government or by government agencies. In other words, there should be some supervision by governmentsânot only the Australian government but governments around the worldâas to what is happening with investment and what is happening with companies of the size of Telstra.

Fifthly, the most important point is that, given all those things, there now ought to be development of some public policy as to how we as a nation are going to handle the flow of capital and how we are going to handle what that capital does. The useful exercise of capital is to build up business. We have got to look at what businesses it builds up and how those businesses operate within the marketplace, and so form a national policy and then an international policy which will produce the goods we are looking for. Then we need to look at how the goods, the capital or the products of the various companies we are talking about will be distributed fairlyâthis is perhaps the part that is not looked at enough these daysânot only within Australia but around the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 24 March 1999, on motion by Senator Watson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

talk.start.para: âYesterday I was speaking about my support for the motion moved by Senator West, particularly those aspects that relate to the actions of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Reith, who undertook most disgraceful and most inappropriate action in orchestrating witnesses to appear before a Senate committee, under the cover of departmental witness es, in such a manner as to provide aid and comfort to this government in its campaign to impose upon the workers of this country further attacks upon their conditions and their employment security in the matter of the unfair dismissals laws that they were proposing.

speech.para: In January this year, the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee inquired into this proposed law and heard witnesses from a range of backgrounds and from a range of organisations, yet this government, in a most sneaky and underhand manner, sought to bring to this committee as witnesses private citizens who appeared together with departmental witnesses. I was the deputy chair of the Senate committee, and I asked the committee to refer this matter to the Procedure Committee. The Procedure Committee has agreed that this is a most inappropriate action and, in its report, highlights:

Following a hearing of the Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee on the unfair dismissals legislation, concern was expressed at the action of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business in bringing private witnesses with officers of the department who were to appear before the committee, with the intention that the evidence of those witnesses support the bill.
It went on to say:

The Procedure Committee considers that it would be highly undesirable, from the standpoint of both the Senate and the government, for departments to fall into this practice, particularly in inquiries by legislation committees into bills.
It further says:

It is not the role of the departments to be gathering private witnesses in support of a bill and insinuating them into committee hearings under the cover of an appearance by departmental officers. Such private witnesses, if they are invited by the committee to appear, should be heard separately.
Clearly these are views that I strongly endorse.

Of course I understand that this is not a contentious propositionâthat all senators would naturally agree with this report. The evidence that was heard in the estimates committee demonstrated quite clearly the deep involvement of this minister in these disgraceful actions. The committee resolved, after discussion, that it would report this matter to the Senate and that the committee would write to all ministers indicating that this practice is inappropriate and that if witness expenses are to be paid by others this should be known to the committees concerned.

These actions came about as a result of an invitation that was issued through the minister's office and the department for Mr Clive and Bryce Tonkin from Adelaide and Mr Frank Denvir and Mr Clement Maloney from Melbourne to fly to Canberra at departmental expense, at a cost of $2,268.60, and to appear before the committee with departmental officers. This was a most inappropriate course of action, as it was apparent that at least one of the witnesses was currently engaged in a matter before courts in this country and that other witnesses were involved in matters which had nothing whatsoever to do with the current law insofar as the unfair dismissal concerns they had related to state legislation, not to federal or Commonwealth law.

I must say that these witnesses must feel terribly badly treated in all of this, because I do not believe that they personally were necessarily involved in any action that was inappropriate but that they in good faith would have been asked by the government to come along and give their views. I can understand citizens wanting to do that. What they would not have understood is that they were being used in a cheap and tawdry political stunt to be the paid cheer squad for departmental officers who were obviously short on strong argument to defend the government's position.

When Mr Denvir spoke to the Australian newspaper, as reported on 9 February this year, he said that `the visit to Canberra had left him out of pocket and had also cost him a day's lost work.' Mr Clive Tonkin said, `I was more than happy to pay my own expenses.' Yet the government, with all the largesse that governments have when they are trying to engage in these sorts of political stunts, paid the expenses of these witnesses to appear.

The department and a senior officer of the department, Dr Shergold, indicated that it was the minister's office that suggested this course of action. And given the minister's involvement in the conspiracy matters associated with the Dubai affair, one could expect the concern that officers would have about being told that they should comply. I am very disappointed, however, that departmental officers sought to act in this way, because what apparently occurred, from the evidence we had, is that Dr Shergold apparently made little attempt to evaluate the evidence that was likely to be presented by these witnesses, and he obviously did not give any consideration to the unprecedented actions that were being embarked upon in the use of private witnesses appearing with departmental witnesses in this way. He had not understood that two of the witnesses were to give testimony about matters that had nothing to do with the Commonwealth law. He had obviously not thought about the involvement of Mr Maloney in the dispute before AIRC and that therefore, in my judgment, it was sub judice for him to appear.

What had occurred was that a junior clerk had been assigned the task of providing a cursory glance at possible witnesses to meet the minister's request to find suitable persons who could fill the role as cheer squad members. We understand that the department undertook to provide these names, but it was the minister's office that finally came up with them; it was the minister's office that came up with the stunt; and it was the minister's office that manipulated the normal departmental processes in engaging the department to facilitate these actions. And it was the coalition members of the committee that went along with these inappropriate actions.

An important consideration that does arise is whether this action is strictly speaking within the standing orders and should be put to one side. But we all know the precedents that are being set and how wrong it is for departments to act in this way. While there may not be, strictly speaking, anything in the standing orders to prevent a party from paying the expenses of witnesses before committ eesâwe all understand there is a provision within the standing orders to allow that to occurâit may however be a contempt of the Senate. I certainly believe that the Senate is being treated in a contemptuous way by this minister.

It may be contempt in that payments may be made by departments while seeking to deliberately conceal them from a committee, particularly in conjunction with circumstances where the committee could be misled as to the status of such witnesses or the nature of the evidence that they are about to present. It may well be that payment is made in an attempt to influence a witness as to the nature of the evidence that the witness should be giving and that the evidence may be tainted by the actions of the department in providing this inducement. It may well be that payments associated with this form of action may be an improper attempt to influence the character of evidence being given.

For those reasons, while I think there may not necessarily be procedural barriers to this action occurring, it is totally inappropriate. And therefore I support the view that the President of the Senate should be writing to all departmental secretaries and government ministers and telling them that this is just not on; that this is not an appropriate course of action to be embarked upon by this government.

We know that this government have a contempt for the parliamentary processes. We have seen it in the way in which they have sought to rort the Senate's voting system when they have advocated positions to undermine the authority of the Senate when it suits them. They are obviously not happy with the use of the Senate legislation committees to inquire into legislation, particularly extremely unpopular, unfair and unreasonable legislation, such as the unfair dismissals legislation. And of course it may well be that they think it is their right to impose witnesses in this way but, quite clearly, this is not action that ought to be countenanced by this Senate. And now that it has been exposed, I trust that action will be taken within government to ensure that this never happens again.

I think it is important for the Senate to appreciate the implications of this case. I am hopeful that all senators will agree that this is not the sort of behaviour that one expects from ministersâeven ministers such as Mr Reith, who has clearly demonstrated his view of how politics is to be performed in this country and has demonstrated again and again that he is quite prepared to pursue any stratagem, no matter what its moral or ethical implications might be, in the pursuit of his narrow political objectives.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Question resolved in the affirmative on the following orders of the day without further debate during consideration of committee reports and government responses:
PrivilegesâStanding Committeeâ75th reportâExecution of search warrants in senators' offices
Foreign Affairs, Defence and TradeâJoint Standing CommitteeâReportâLoss of HMAS Sydney

talk.start.para: âOrder! There being no further consideration of committee reports and government responses, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âFor AFL football fans, this day, Thursday 25 March, is an auspicious one, marking the start of an eagerly awaited 1999 home and away AFL footy season. At the outset, I should declare some personal interest in tonight's debateâI have to admit to being an avid Essendon fan. It is not as bad as being a Carlton fan, I guess. It just so happens that the mighty Bombers are playing their first game of the season tonight against Carlton. Many residents of my electorate of the Northern Territory are fanatical followers of Australian football. AFL plays a very important part in their lives, as indeed it does for a lot of Australians, especially Victorians.

speech.para: As you may know, over the years the Territory has produced some outstanding AFL footballers, people like Maurice Rioliânow a Territory Labor MLA, Michael Long, Andrew McLeod, Robbie AhMat and Mark West, just to name a few. However, the issue that I want to speak about tonight is that the residents of the majority of remote Territory communitiesâwhose residents, I should add, are predominantly Aboriginalâwill be missing out on watching broadcasts of the AFL games. They have already missed out on watching the excitement of the preseason Ansett Cup competition. Football is big in the Territory's Aboriginal communities. Young Aboriginal kids love to play and love to watch.

Football is a big community event. If you visit any of the Territory's remote communities, you will always see young Aboriginal kids playing football, emulating their AFL heroes, wearing their jumpers. I am thinking of such Top End communities as Barunga, Daguragu, Pine Creek, Milingimbi, Yirrkala and Mataranka; and Central Australian communities such as Areyonga, Yuendumu, Santa Teresa, Willowra, Nyirrpi, Hermannsburg, Wallace Rockhole, Mutitjulu and Docker Riverâand the list goes on. These are remote communities, mad keen on AFL football and now unable to watch the Channel 7 footy broadcasts. I should also point out that many communities in the area of South Australia stretching from Moomba to Ceduna, which also receive Imparja broadcasts, may miss out on AFL broadcasts.

Next week I intend to table a petition signed by over 400 Territorians living in remote locations, who are upset that they cannot access AFL broadcasts in their communities. How did this happen, and why am I on my feet in the Senate to talk about this? On 23 December last year, the Australian Broadcasting Authority extended the broadcast areas of the Aboriginal owned Imparja Television, which broadcasts out of Alice Springs, and the Telecasters owned television station, then a Channel 10 affiliate, which broadcasts out of Townsville. The extension of their broadcasting licences allows Channel 7 Central and Imparja to broadcast into each other's broadcast areas. This move gave viewers access, theoretically anyway, to two commercial channels.

At the same time, Telecasters decided to become an affiliate of Channel 7 Network from 1 February this year, giving them full access to Seven Network programming, including the AFL. As a result, Imparja, which had broadcast AFL games to remote communities via satellite for the past 10 or so years, lost the right to show AFL gamesâmeaning that those communities that only get Imparja can no longer automatically watch the AFL broadcasts.

As a result of all this, these remote communities have three alternatives. They can keep Imparja, and go without Channel 7 Central and the football; they can choose to give up Imparjaâwith its local news, Aboriginal programs and other programmingâand switch over to Channel 7 Central; or they can purchase the additional decoder and apply to the Australian Broadcasting Authority for a licence that would allow them to access and retransmit the additional commercial channel. However, if they decide to proceed with the latterâwhich is the most preferable because it gives them access to all TV channelsâand buy the equipment, they need to find anywhere between $8,000 and $30,000, depending on whether they are a self-help or BRACS community, and depending on what transponders and transmission equipment they need.

For many remote communities, many of which are impoverished and barely managing with the local government funding they receive, that sort of money is simply out of the reach of most of them. Channel 7 Central has said it will install the necessary retransmission equipment, but only in communities larger than 2,000 people. However, this excludes the Territory's remote communities, which vary in size from about 400 to 1,000 people. I believe that the Territory's remote communities are entitled to access the AFL on the same terms as other Australians do. I firmly believe that a universal service obligation should be introduced for Australia's broadcasting services to ensure that all Australians have access to a range of broadcasting servicesâincluding broadcasts of what is, after all, Australia's national game, AFL. As was pointed out in the report on Communications with Australia's External Territories, which was tabled in the Senate this week:

Broadcasting services are not just a commercial matter. They influence both cultural identity and the Australian people's sense of national integration. For this reason it is in Australia's long term interest to ensure that all Australians receive a variety of Australian broadcast services through clear and reliable signals.

Last week, in what can only be described as a very cynical move aimed at softening up the Senate for the debate on the further sale of Telstra, the federal government announced it would allocate funds to improve broadcasting services to remote and regional communities.

The government said this move would give BRACS, the Broadcasting in Remote Aboriginal Communities Scheme, and `self-help' communities in remote areas of Australia access to a second commercial channel and hence access to AFL football broadcasts. Self-help communities are those communities which decided not to install individual decoder dishes but instead bought a community transmitter. The funding would help them buy additional transmitters and a satellite decoder by providing for 75 per cent of the cost of the purchase. But, and here's the catch, these funds would come from the further sale of Telstra, which the government had hoped the Senate would pass this week.

However, we saw what happened with the government's Telstra bill this week. At the last moment, after a few hours of debate, the government pulled the bill from the Senate for an `indefinite' period of time. I am glad the bill has been pulled because I do not believe the sale of Telstra will benefit my constituents in the Northern Territory. It would simply lead to a reduction in the quality of telecommunication services. I also do not believe that the provision of adequate broadcasting services to Australians living in remote communities should be dependent on the further sale of Telstra. Instead, the federal government should ensure access to broadcasting services is provided to all Australians as a right, independent of Telstra's future.

The federal government has made a mess of the aggregation process involving Imparja and Channel 7 Central. It should have ensured that viewers would be able to maintain the existing viewing, especially programs such as AFL broadcasts, or rugby league, in the case of Northern Queensland viewers. The least the federal government can do now, in the short term, is immediately ensure that Imparja is given the right to broadcast AFL games for the 1999 year or until all remote communities are able to access the additional commercial channel.

Senator Alston should immediately call the AFL, Channel 7 Central and Imparja together to find a short-term solution so that those residents of remote communities can access those AFL broadcasts. The most obvious solution to the problem in the short term is for Channel 7 Central to allow a program swap, which would meet the needs of both stations' viewers in the short term. I also point out that Senator Ian Macdonald, the minister for territories, speaking on ABC radio last week misled Territorians by saying that Channel 7 and Imparja had agreed to a temporary program swap. When the stations were asked about this program swap, they knew nothing about it. It makes you wonder if this government knows what is actually happening in remote and regional Australia. Imagine the outcry if Australians living in Melbourne or Sydney suddenly found they couldn't access the AFL or the cricket.

It is simply not good enough for the federal government to ignore the problem or to promise that all the problems will be solved by the privatisation of Telstra. The government is being irresponsible in getting the hopes up of those residents of remote communities and using them as political footballs in this outrageous debate. I call on the government to act immediately to ensure that residents of remote communities have adequate broadcasting services and that all Territorians can access their footy.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to inform the Senate and the general public of a conspiracy between the state ALP government and the union movement which is going to cost the youth of Australia thousands of jobs by undermining the very successful Work for the Dole project.

speech.para: Senator O'Brien interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI will get on to that, Senator. If you want me to refer to regional Australia, I will give you some figures on that. Last week, I was lucky enough to present the graduate certificates to two of these Work for the Dole projects in northern New South Wales. One was at the Walka Water Works in the federal electorate of Patterson and the other was the Mingara Centre in the federal seat of Dobell. The Walka Water Works scheme employed 180 local unemployed youth, with 80 per cent of them expressing satisfaction with the program and 30 per cent of them coming out of this with full-time jobs. Nationally, the average is higher, with 32 per cent of long-term unemployed emerging with full-time work and 10 per cent going on to further education and training.

speech.para: But if the ALP and the unions had their way, this program would not have existed. Sixty young people in the seat of Patterson and 40 in the seat of Dobell would still be unemployed or not be taking it upon themselves to do further formal training. Despite the weight of evidence that the Work for the Dole scheme has been an outstanding success, the state ALP and their union co-conspirators are trying to block its path. The Australian Workers Union has this month blocked five Work for the Dole projects in New South Wales. These would have occupied more than 500 people who have been long-term unemployed in the towns of Port Macquarie, Armidale, Dorrigo, Grafton and South West Rocks.

On average, 200 young people who participated in the courses would have come out with a formal qualification and a job. But, because of one intransigent union official in a Sydney office, that has all been blocked and all of those young people will miss out on a job. That is 200 jobs in rural and regional Australia thrown away. The five projects to be undertaken in these towns were supported by the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the local union organisers. But it was the state organiser, who obviously did not understand what was going on and did not understand the need for jobs in this area, who actually blocked it.

Across the country, this scheme has been working very successfully. The Howard government has now put in place 412 Work for the Dole programs, employing 18,000 young people. That is about to expand over the next four years to 125,000 long-term unemployed being given the opportunity to gain a job. That translates, on current trends, into 40,000 people in work, and 12,500 more people in formal education.

It is much more successful than the Labor government's failed Working Nation program. It is returning on average 32 per cent long-term unemployed into the work force, at a cost of $3,900, on average, compared to the enormous costs that existed under Labor's failed Working Nation program. We all remember the hundreds of millions of dollars that were wasted on that.

talk.start.para: âWhat was the percentage out of LEAP?

âWe have a more effective and efficient program, Senator Forshaw. We are getting better job outcomes at a much lower rateâ32 per cent is higher than Working Nation, and $3,900 is a hell of a lot lower than the $52,000 that your New Work Opportunities Program was costing. Senator Forshaw has gone quiet, and it is no wonder. Senator Forshaw should listen to some of his colleagues. I suggest he listens to and reads the work of the member for Melbourne, Lindsay Tanner, and of the member for Werriwa, Mark Latham. If Senator Forshaw listens to what they have to say, and reads what they have written about this, he will find that they tend to agree more with me than they do with himâwhich is why, I assume, one of them is languishing on the back bench.

speech.para: Returning to the initial program where we are trying to expand Work for the Dole, it is very unfortunate that Premier Carr and the unions have stopped this going ahead. This is in line of course with the federal ALP's very negative policy towards employment. The Beazley opposition has opposed the unfair dismissalâ

talk.start.para: âSenator, you should not refer to the Leader of the Opposition in that fashion.

âI am sorry; the Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Kim Beazley. His opposition has opposed unfair dismissal provisions. Initially we had estimates that the reform was going to create another 50,000 jobs, but in evidence before Senate committee hearings respected business councils are now telling us that it could somewhere between 100,000 and 200,000 jobs.

speech.para: But this opposition is blocking that. It also vetoed youth wage rates, putting at risk the job security of 420,000 young Australians. We are not talking about new measures here. We are talking about measures that are in place which, because of the discrimination act, will cease next year unless the Senate amends it. To keep the current arrangements in place the Senate has to amend it. This opposition has refused to do that and puts at risk current jobs. You are not talking about creating new jobs; you are putting at risk up to 420,000 current jobs.

They have opposed legislation to extend mutual obligation, which is the foundation for such things as Work for the Dole. They have also rejected the coalition's enhanced apprenticeship scheme. We really have to ask this Labor opposition why they are so anti work. Why are they so anti programs that are going to put people in work? Why do they continually oppose in this chamber legislation which will assist programs that will give people real jobs?

Let me go back to what we were trying to do with Work for the Dole initially and see how Labor measure up now. We aimed to develop work habits in young people, to involve the local community in quality projects provided for these people, to help the young unemployed at the end of the projects to achieve real jobs and to provide communities with projects in their local communityâsuch as the ones I saw at Walka Water Worksâwhich will improve their standard. Everything, as far as this program has travelled to date, indicates success, and continuing success will come with the government's dramatic expansion of this program over the next few years.

The young people I met at Walka Water Works and at the Mingara Centre were very heartened by their experience. There were very positive comments from them, their parents and the local community that was benefiting from these projects. It is obviously easier for the opposition to sit back and knock everything this government is doing for unemployment rather than try to support outcomes that will provide the youth of this nation with real jobs.

talk.start.para: âOn Sunday, 21 March 1999, the 60 Minutes program provided to the Australian people a devastating expose of former Labor leader Keating's financial transactions associated with his now infamous piggery. In typical Keatingesque style, he denied the allegations with a flourish. He called them a `hatchet job'. The Sydney Morning Herald reported on 23 March 1999 at page 7:

speech.para: Mr Keating said after the program screened on Sunday night that the "option did exist".
"It was not owned by me," he said. "But even if it had been, I was not required to disclose it."

Given that the option existed, the former Labor leader's other quotable quoteâreported in the editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 March 1999 at page 16âneeds full analysis. In that editorial the former Labor leader is quoted as saying:
"Everything I told Parliament was completely correct" . . .

So what did the former Labor leader tell the parliament? In answer to an opposition question on this very matter, dealing with the piggery and his personal financial transactions, the former Labor leader told the House of Representatives on 24 March 1994âthat is exactly five years and one day agoâthat:
The honourable gentlemanâ
referring to Mr McLachlan, the then member for Barkerâ
seems to know much, but he does not know that I disposed of my interest in this business nearly two weeks ago. He does not know that, but I am telling him.

So Labor's former leader, Mr Keating, announced to the world that he had disposed of his interest. Because he was not forthcoming with proof, we had to accept that assertion. However, it is now quite clear that the former Labor leader sold his shares but, in a slick deal, retained an interestâcontrary to what he told the parliamentâby retaining an option to buy back. Either he or a company with which he was associated held that option. The option was later sold for over $1 million. It would not be an exaggeration to claim that one million dollars plus is an interest, indeed a substantial interest.

An option is clearly an interest. As the value of the company increases, so does the value of the option, and therefore pulling strings or doing things to advantage the company are actions which increase the value of the optionâa very clear interest in anyone's language. As such, there existed a responsibility to disclose the option. Indeed the former Labor leader appeared in 1975âsome 20 years earlier, before he pulled this particular stuntâbefore a parliamentary committee setting rules for disclosing members' outside interests. A report of the Hansard shows Keating gave the hypothetical example of an MP being able to hide a profit if he had:

"an option to purchase for an infinitesimal amount, a property or shares, at sometime in the future, and only one copy ever existed and that was with the member himselfâno-one", said Keating, "could ever say that had received it."

All hypothetical of course, but not so hypothetical in this case because, as has now been revealed, this is exactly what the former Labor leader did. The state of the evidence is now very clear. Mr Keating, the former Labor leader, did mislead the Houseâno splitting of hairs. No silver-tongued apologist can deny that. This should be a matter of grave concern to all honourable senators and members and to all Australians.

talk.start.para: âAs all senators would be aware, there is an election this coming Saturday for the lower and upper houses of the New South Wales parliament. From virtually all reports it seems likely that the government of Mr Carr is going to be returned. What is certainly far less clear is what the outcome is going to be in the upper house. That is an issue of great importanceâI do not need to convince anyone in this chamber of the importance of upper houses and the vital role they play in ensuring some sort of parliamentary check on the role of the government of the day.
âThat is why you haven't got one in Queensland.

âAs Senator Forshaw said, it is a great shameâI think that is what he said; I am sure he would have said that it is a great shameâthat we do not have one in Queensland. We have seen some of the unfortunate impacts in my own state of Queensland of not having a proper degree of parliamentary scrutiny of the actions of government. Nonetheless, it is important that the representatives of any parliamentary chamber are capable people elected under a system that has the confidence of the people and that is suitably democratic.

speech.para: A lot of attention has been paid to the size of the ballot paper in the upper house in New South Wales, which is due to the ability of people to get elected virtually entirely on the basis of undertaking arrangements in relation to preferences with other small groups without having to get any significant degree of support from the general public. The big difference between that chamber and any other upper house is that, in any other proportional system that operates within Australia, a candidate is rarely able to get elected unless they have a significant proportion of public support; the basis then being that the preference flows from excluded candidates provide a greater opportunity for the proper democratic wishes of the public to be reflected in the eventual outcome in the chamber.

What is probably even more disconcerting in relation to the situation in New South Walesâapart from the people that the public basically knows nothing about, many of whom are unable to be contactedâis the ability of people to register themselves as a party. There is no requirement for that party name to accurately represent what that organisation is about, enabling them to completely misrepresent what they are about.

Perhaps one of the most obvious examples is a party that was registered as the Animal Liberation Party. The registered officer and certainly any members that have been able to be identified of that party have no connection with the Animal Liberation organisation in New South Wales. There is no commonality of membership and no commonality of purpose. Any reasonable person who sees a party called the Animal Liberation Party would assume that they had some connection with or support from Animal Liberation in that state. Clearly that is not the case in this situation.

We have a party that is basically standing under false pretences, giving a completely false indication of what their support base is and what their philosophy is about. Apart from the potential to mislead the voters, this also leads to the potential for the genuine organisationâand I use the Animal Liberation organisation by way of exampleâto be discredited by any statements or actions by people who are registered under that name.

It is a matter that is of great concern to the Democrats because it does bring the democratic system into disrepute. The crucial aspect of retaining what is left of public support for the democratic system and for our system of government is to ensure that the public has confidence in the electoral system and confidence in the accuracy of what people stand for when they stand for election. When the balance between being able to democratically choose and ensuring that the representation of parliament accurately reflects the views of the population is weakened by a system that has the potential to end up being not much more than a lottery, obviously the confidence of the public in that system can be significantly reduced.

This is an issue that, certainly as a member of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Electoral Matters, I will be pursuing with interest, particularly in terms of the ability of people to register under a party name that implies association with an existing and well-known community organisation. The example I gave of the Animal Liberation Party is but one of many parties that will be standing on Saturday for election to the New South Wales upper house. A number of other parties have registered under names that give quite a misleading indication of what their actual association and orientation is about. That can only be bad for democracy.

The Democrats, as honourable senators would know, have long supported a proportional representation form of voting. That voting system is one that we believe is strongly supported by the public because it does provide an outcome that most accurately reflects the views of the public. That is why chambers such as the Senate have strong support amongst the public. They know that its composition more fairly and accurately represents the views of people. They feel less disenfranchised than they do under systems such as those that operate in the lower house.

The situation in the New South Wales upper house is unfortunate, not specifically because of it being proportional representation but as much because of the great degree of ease with which people can register as a political party and pass themselves off as something other than what they represent. Perhaps more to the point, they can pass themselves off as a legitimate political partyâand clearly a large proportion of those standing on the weekend are not legitimate. When people are able to register a political party purely as a publicity stunt for their commercial television program, that is a situation with the potential to further devalue the confidence people have in the democratic system. In that circumstance, I believe this is an issue that needs to be examined.

We are fortunate that we do not have a problem of that degree at the federal level. Certainly I will be keen to ensure that the problems that have been evident in New South Wales do not repeat themselves at the federal level. I am sure many parties in New South Wales will also be trying to ensure that the system there is modified so that a more reputable and democratic system is in operation.

In closing, as a reaffirmation of the importance of the democratic process, I wish all candidates of all parties and persuasions the best on Saturday. I think it is important that people do participate in the political process. It is always a positive thing to have community debate and to have the opportunity for people to have a say as to who will represent them in their parliamentary system. In relation to the very important role of the upper house, I do urge the voters of New South Wales to think carefully, take the time to unfold that beach towel of a ballot paper and make sure they realise that they will be stuck for eight years with whoever they put a No. 1 next to. It is an important choice and I urge them to think carefully before they cast their vote.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 March 1999:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 1279 (Senate Hansard , 4 May 1994, p.273):
(1) Have the Beeliar Wetlands been listed on the Register of the National Estate, if so; when were they gazetted.

(2) If they have not been listed on the Register of the National Estate, why has this not been done, given the former Minister's (Senator Faulkner) commitment that they would be listed for the gazettal notice late in 1994.

(3) Given that the guidelines for assessing the priority of assessment of National Estate listing includes reference to whether Commonwealth decisions are pending, why has the Beeliar listing not been given priority for assessment despite the fact that the Commonwealth is committing funds for the development of a major port facility in the region of the Beeliar wetlands at Jervoise Bay.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Beeliar Wetlands were entered in the Interim List of the Register of the National Estate on 6 December 1994 by publication, in the Gazette and the press, by the Australian Heritage Commission of a notice of intention to enter the wetlands in the Register. They have not yet been entered in the Register proper.

(2) Before a place can be entered in the Register, the Australian Heritage Commission must give due consideration to any objections to the intention to do so. Objections were received, and after independent assessment, were formally considered by the Commission on 25 November 1996. As a result the Commission decided to redefine the boundaries of the place and re-enter the place in the Interim List as `Beeliar Regional Park and Adjacent Areas'. A notice of intention to register the redefined area was published in the Gazette and press on 24 June 1997.

No objections were received to the registration of the redefined area, however issues did arise in relation to the exact boundary of the park as defined by the Western Australian Ministry for Planning. Resolution of these issues is being pursued by the Commission to allow finalisation of the registration of the place.

(3) The guidelines referred to by the honourable senator are used by the Commission to set a priority for assessment for the initial step in registration, ie entry in the Interim List. The wetlands are in the Interim List and by virtue of section 31 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 are deemed to be in the Register for the purposes of protection under that Act.
